titleStmt.author: anon.

editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

respStmt.resp: Incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words were reviewed and in many cases fixed by
respStmt.name: Hannah Bredar

respStmt.resp: Tokenization and linguistic annotation using MorphAdorner and NUPOS 2.0 were provided by
respStmt.name: Philip R. Burns

respStmt.resp: With the help of Thomas L. Berger's Index of Characters in Early Modern English Drama Printed Plays, 1500-1660 speech prefixes were mapped to unique "who" attributes of sp elements by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: A provisional, rudimentry, and algorithmically produced castlist was added as a new div in the back listing each role with their number of speeches sorted from high to low by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: Project co-ordination and review of textual changes and linguistic annotation by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

div.p: A pleasant comedy, called the two merry milkmaids. Or, the best words wear the garland. As it was acted before the King, with general approbation, by the company of the revels. By I. c.
London, printed by Bernard Alsop for Lawrence Chapman, and are to be sold at his shop in Holborn over against 〈…〉 ple inn hard by the bars. 1620.

list.item: Bernard, son to Guido, and student at Wittenberg.
Frederick, son to Lodwick, and brother to Dorigene.

Ferdinand,
Cornelio,
Carolus,courtiers, and servants to lord Raymond.
Julia, a lady familiar with the Duchess.

div.head: The Printer to the reader.
div.p: Every writer must govern his pen according to the capacity of the stage he writes too, both in the actor and the auditor. This had the happiness to please, as it was means, the greater part, and of them not the worst. If there be discovery made of the coniuring words, you'll find the witchcraft: no true spirit will be stirred with 'em; haply, a malicious. It was made more for the eye, than the ear; less for the hand, then either: and had not false copies travailed abroad (Even to surbating) this had kept in; for so far the author was from seeking fame in the publishing, that he could have wished it bound about with the King. Some good words here you shall find for your money, else it keeps not touch with the title. Receive it well, and though in this he give you no ill, yet hereafter he hath promised you better language.

lg.l: This day we entreat all that are hither come,
To expect no noise of guns, trumpets, nor drum,
Nor sword and target; but to hear sense and words,
Fitting the matter that the scene affords.
So that the stage being reformed, and free
From the loud clamours it was wont to be,
Turmoiled with battles; you I hope will cease
Your daily tumults, and with us wish peace.
We stand a hazard now: yet being prepared,
We hope, for your own good, you in the yard
Will lend your ears, attentively to hear
Things that shall flow so smoothly to your ear;
That you returning home, t'your friends shall say,
Howe'er you understand't, 'tis a fine play:
For we have in't a conjurer, a devil,
And a clown too; but I fear the evil,
In which perhaps unwisely we may fail,
Of wanting squibs and crackers at their tail.
But howsoever, gentlemen I swear,
You shall have good words for your money here;
Stuff that will last, we hope, and died in grain:
And as ye liked, pray know the house again.

body.head: A pleasant comedy of the merry milkmaids.

sp.stage: Enter Bernard in his study, candle and books about him.
sp.l: Enchantments pluck out of the sky
The moon, though she be placed on high.
Dame Circe's, with her charms so fine.
Ulysses' mates did turn to swine:
The snakes with charm is burst in twain,
In meadows where she doth remain.
And here again,
She plucks each star out of his seat,
And turneth back the raging waves;
With charms she makes the earth to sweat,
And raiseth souls out of their graves:
She burns men's bones as with a fire,
And pulleth down the lights of heaven,
And makes it snow at her desire,
Even in the midst of summer season;
and what is it cannot be done
By art of the magician?
'Tis true, things most incredible are to be done,
And I believe thee gentle book in it.
Never before my wary tutor did
Leave this door open, which he well might call
His private study; for here secrets lie
Were worth man's labour to arrive to 'em:
Here are the names, shapes, powers, and government
Of every several spirit, their degrees,
Their great effects, particular signories;
And amongst them I have found one, if I had
But skill to raise him for my purposes,
And here's the form of it set down at large:
But stay, what's this?
sp.stage: Amaymon King of the East, Gorson King of the South, Zimimar King of the North, Goap King and prince of the West, may be bound from the third hour till noon, Dukes may be bound from the first hour till noon.
sp.l: Pish, this is naught to me.
sp.stage: Asmody; a great King, strong and mighty, he is seen with three heads; whereof the first is like a bull, the second a man, the third a ram: he hath a serpent's tail, he belcheth flames out of his mouth, he sitteth on an infernal dragon, he carrieth a lance and a flag in his hand, he goeth before others which are under the power of Amaymon, he giveth the ring of virtues, he teacheth geometry, arithmetic, astronomy; to all demands he answereth fully and truly: he maketh a man invisible.
sp.l: Ay, this.
sp.stage: He showeth the places where treasure lie.
sp.l: I do not care for treasure.
This, this is it: great Asmody, thou art the spirit whom
I would converse with, and I will fetch thee, if this
Charm will do it. —
sp.p: Now I have laid my circle, fear assaults me: so says my grave instructor all men do when they begin this business; but bids me here be resolute, and dread not: for bound in this circle, and by these words constrained, they cannot hurt me.
sp.l: I do conjure thee by these potent names:
sp.stage: Panthon, Adonay, Algramay, Planaboth, Muriton, Bisecognaton, Siston, Diaton, Maton, tetragrammaton, Agla, Agarion, Tegra, Pentessaron, Tendicata, Sorthie, Sorthia, Sorthios, Milia, Achilia, Sibylia, you the three fairy sisters of the ring come and appear to me, or send your faithful servant Asmody, or I will call the five Kings of the North.
Enter Landoffe his tutor like a spirit.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: For what thou daring mortal? what wilt thou do with Asmody, now thou hast brought him hither?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: I do command thee that thou help me to the invisible ring.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Ho, ho, ho, thou foolish thing without art, and
Less wit, dost think it doth require no more but so?
It is thy master's masterpiece to do it,
And thou dost call for nothing but thy ruin.
Thou art now in my power, and I can tear thee
As small as atomies, and throw thee off
Like dust before a wind: yet for I know thou art
Pupil unto my master, and his minion,
and mayst hereafter with a word release me,
Here unconstrained, I vow myself thy servant,
And will (Acquaint me with thy purposes)
Effect them to the utmost of my power.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Dost thou not this in subtlety, to draw me out of my circle, and then ruin me?

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: I dare as well run on the fiery sword that wounds Malantha, Thama, or Sitrami.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: I do believe thee:
Then be gone; yet stay, a word more:
sp.p: Thinks thou my tutor; if I should conceal this act of mine from him, that he would know it?

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: I think not: for he hath given me liberty these five days.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Thanks Asmody: now leave me.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: I am gone.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: I will get leave of him to return back unto my father's house, where I will live, if Asmody can do it, invisible.
sp.l: Not far off is a damsel whom I love,
But never yet durst tell her, nor did know it
So feelingly, as now I am removed.
'Tis almost day I wished, though not for fear,
For love has made me a bold conjurer.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: And thou wert bold indeed: but youth is desperate ;
Respects not dangers, howsoe'er they look. ;
I came myself unto this art with trembling,
And when I first had raised a spirit up,
My flesh methought ran like my blood about me,
And I sat bathed in a cold faint swear.
But he was far from raising any spirit:
He ran 'em so disordered, that no devil,
though he had heard him, would have known his name.
But it was my device, seeing him grow
To extreme melancholy and discontent,
To let him view these scattered papers thus,
That I might sound his grief, knowing how apt
And covetous youth is of every knowledge,
If he might learn it with a little babbling:
But this is not an art so to be gained.
I'll follow him, attending still upon him,
As if I were the spirit he guesses me:
And if there shall be cause, I'll play my part
So well, that men shall praise the magic art.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Good signior no more eruptions, I tell you what you shall trust to: I am not like a mill, to be turned with wind and water; not all your sighs and tears can alter me, keep 'em for custard-eating dames i'th' city, there they may prosper.
sp.l: Thou art a handsome fellow, I confess it,
Hast good parts too, I know it; living sufficient
To keep house i'th' country, and invite
Every good time thy neighbours, and at Christmas '
Distribute amongst the poor six pence apiece,
And a brown loaf: good country virtues these,
And may perhaps serve for a doctor's daughter,
Though she have read Orlando Furioso.
But for me, that have looked higher into poetry,
And for a need can couple of myself,
have talked with Montaigne and with Machiavel,
And can make use of them; note him in this
Place shallow, here profound: and be th'only star
Whereto all wits advance their Jacob's staff,
And the supreme cry me out excellent.
What would three hundred pound a year do here?
'Twill keep a blue coat and a side saddle,
But not maintain my coach-horses in provender.

sp.speaker: Doril.
sp.l: Most excellent of women, that you are worthy
All that your hopes can lodge in you, I grant:
But fortune and the graces were at odds
When you were gotten, else you had been made
As great as dignity can make a woman.
But yet you know (I pray forgive my plainness)
That in estate you do not equal me,
If that were it I looked at.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: 'Tis true:
I think my portion is some seven score pound,
And hardly that by’r lady: what 'tis I know not,
It lies above in the garret in old rusty armour.
But what's that to th'purpose: there's a spirit
(Good or bad, I know not) whispers unto me;
Be an empress wench, a Queen, or Duchess,
Countess, or marquess at least, for those are trifles.
sp.p: Now I'll tell thee Dorilus, because thou art a handsome fellow, as I told thee before; when I am any one of these, thou shalt enjoy me, in plain terms, lie with me, and make a cuckold: for my ambition is to advance greatness. Look, here's thy sister.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Come in a time I doubt to make you blush.
Why what mad conference are you two in?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: For my ambition is to advance greatness.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: As how?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Why as a woman may do; the manner is not to be shown now. I am glad thou art come to take off thy brother.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Take him off, why he is not so fierce, methinks :
What, do you weep brother?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Like a watering-pot; he would make an excellent
Fountain in the midst of a garden.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: A moist milksop lover, hang him, on whom love has no more operation than an onion: why, did not I tell you this was the wrong way, and taught you the right; lectured unto you according to my own heart, and my heart is made of the same stuff that other women's are: for shame leave, it is both an ill sight and an ill sign to see a man drop at the nose.

sp.speaker: Doril.
sp.l: Why you mistake me, if you think I weep.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: No; what use then of your handkercher?

sp.speaker: Doril.
sp.l: Something has touched my eye, that does offend it.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Some feather like a woman.

sp.speaker: Doril.
sp.p: Not so good shuttlecock, your pointed wit stabs desperately at all times. Look you, 'tis thus: if you can love me, fair one, so; if not —

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: So.

sp.speaker: Doril.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: So, so: for he did but so, so, for he did but so, so, and so let her go.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, thou art a mad wench, and haste mercy upon no man, far worse than I.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Not worse; much about one, as the collier to the devil: but what shall we do, shall we not see the Duke?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Yes faith, and thou say'st the word, and laugh him out of his dominions: for to laugh him and all his train out of countenance, is nothing; I have a great mind to jeer the courtiers.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Prithee let's, there requires not much wit about it.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Is't done?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: If my consent will do't, 'tis.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Why then 'tis done, and dun's the mouse, and undone all the courtiers: my father's gone before to meet him.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Yes, I saw him very spruce.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Through out ground he must come, the hour just at milking time.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I'faith 'twere good — ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Why dost thou laugh?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Why I'll tell thee sirrah.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: No sirrah, you sha'not tell me, I wonot lose the glory of the invention, for I know you have found it.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: To go like milkmaids.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: I knew it must out, or thy tongue had burned else,
To go like milk maids, and like milkmaids will we go,
To make sport with the courtiers, and triumph.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: The maids they went a milking
All in a misty morning,
Down went their milking pales,
Up went their terrie diddle dales,
And all was but a milking,
And all was but a milking.
I'faith wenches, are you for employment?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p:
I would my father had bound thee prentice seven years ago to a scrivener, by this time thou hadst
lost thy ears: what make you eavesdrop here? I thought this had not been a sober time of day with you.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: Faith want of money sister is guilty of the sin.
sp.p: Come, supply, supply, or out goes all, I'll spoil your milking business.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: By this light if thou dost, thou shalt starve for want of butter.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: Come, the purse jingles, I hear it,
For music with his silver knell
Rings us all in at the blue bell.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: I must give him some.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Give him all to be rid of him.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: What, you do not mean to go see the Duke, brother?

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: Not I i'faith sister, I have a duck of mine own, that I must visit — tother shilling —

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: I have no more, believe it.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: Pish, I cannot endure this paltering and patching between sister and brother — — so, now go your ways and milk, but take heed of churning; our dairy maid got the toothache with —

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Your mouth's stopped, is't not?

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: Umh.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Why so then, pray God the wenches have clean waistcoats.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: You are resolved then.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Resolved! Thou art a fool Julia, thou shalt see
I will do things beyond credulity.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: This money should ha' bought Tiffenie and Cobweb lawn, and what a sin had that been, to nurse pride, when it may purchase necessary claret?

My father allows me too little, I find that: and it were
not for this good natured pagan, my sister, I knew not what to do, unless I should run my head into a commodity of hemp, and that I must take up at the gallows too, or else they wonot trust me: yet I might have a bargain of crock-butter, if I could get an heir to be bound for't, your country gentlemen have no maw to't; but your cockney were the only man, for he would take it up, and 'twere but to make toasts of.

sp.stage: Enter lord Raymond, Lodwick, Bernard's father, Smirke the clown, with attendants.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: Gentlemen all I thank you, your good wills
To me (As well as to the Duke your loyalty)
Is shown in this your readiness and love.
He cannot be far off: pray let your men
Keep off the country people, that do swarm
As thick as do the city multitude
At sight of any rare solemnity.

sp.speaker: Smirke.
sp.p: Keep back there, keep back, or I'll make your leather pilches cry twango else: for some of them I am sure I made 'em smoke so, that I feared I had set 'em a fire. Foh, some of them have drunk sour butter milk this morning, mingled with garlic, which crudden together, makes but a rank smell: and then they have their Christmas shoes on, their old dancing pumps, up to the middle calf, keeps 'em so warm, that here'll be a perfume for the Duke's own nostrils.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Signior Ranoff, you are well arrived.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.l: And you sweet signior — 'tis very precious hot,
I protest I have been cooler under the line.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: A halter you have.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.l: I would we might command some drink here.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Nay, and we could entreat it, we were happy: for the serving-men that were wont to be all mouths, are now all eyes, they have no other member useful about them.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: This lord has a most dulcet situation, pleasant, and profitable, I have seldom seen in Venice a sweeter.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Did you not see sir a swarm of bees as you passed by?

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.l: I cannot tell indeed, I did not mark 'em.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: methought they looked sir like your people of Hybla.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: I cannot tell, I never had much conversation with your people of Hybla, my noble lord.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Here's another, a bird of the same, but a more tame one, something more quiet. Now to hear this jay chatter, and this owlet hold his peace, but answer him with motion, may serve for a morris-dance.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Your lordship's jennet in my conceit is a most understanding beast.

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.l: Hum.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: I saw the Adlantatho of Domingo mounted upon such another, not much different, nay surely nothing at all; and I do not think but they were twins, only I think your lordships the better.

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.l: Hum.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.l: Your lordship keeps the saddle admirable,

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.l: Hum.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p:
I would your lordship had been with me at Japon, I speak it for horse's sake, and horsemanship together; I protest they are the best riders, if I said the rankest, I did not lie: for believe it, I hold your rank
Ryder a good rider, take him always, and at all times: as your Frenchman, in Christendom I do not know a ranker rider, unless it be some part North, there they are scourers. Your lordship has a most neat ruff, and becomes you most elegantly.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Hum.
sp.stage: Enter Cornelius, with Dorigene and Julia, like milkmaids.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Is not this a fine dialogue? How now? Who come these to milk? my lord and's compeer?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: No, believe it sir, they are taken up for the Duke's own tooth.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: I'd as live thou hadst told me a tale: yet beshrew me they are a couple of handsome calves with white faces; but the degrees of this how comest about?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Why the Duke passing by, cast his eye upon them, and with it, I believe, his fancy: for upon some consideration, he sent back, to give command, they should be brought hither to my lord's house.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: 'Tis not amiss, he does well to begin wholesome.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.l: Will your lordship conduct?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Ay, this will be good, stand aside, and give 'Her law.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.l: Fair gentle milk maid.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Sweet courteous squire.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Good; a wench of language: by this hand I love thee.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Love me sir, why you have scarce looked on me.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.l: That's all one, I protest I love thee,

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: I am sorry for't.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: How which one? sorry for't? sorry-that I, whom ladies languish for, repine, and die?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Surely sir, those ladies are not sound, that die of such a scurvy disease.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.l: You now betray your rudeness; I am angry.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: You show yourself an ass, and I not care for't.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Udfoot, and my dagger had not been rusty, that I might have drawn it with credit, I'd a stuck it in the middle of your milk pale, foolish, scurvy, coarse-kersey, dirty-tailed, dangling dug cow: a gentleman courtier and traveller, whose feet has measured the Alps, and be disgraced in a piece of unplowed pasture.

I have lighted upon one of the Egyptian idols, taughtCallowe stroking up his hair, compliments with faces and legs.with some engine to put off his hat, and screw his face a little: I cannot speak to it like a man, yet I will talk to it as if it were one. How came you hither sir, pray did you ride, or were you drawn in a cart?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Hum

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Nay, believe it my lord, they are a brace of the rudest baubees that ever drew or sucked the milk of innocence.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Why, but he is not a lord, I hope, sir?

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Foolish wench I tell thee he is a lord, and I am little less myself, if I were in place where: what dost thou know, but I may be the Duke?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Marry God forbid, sir.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Why, it had been all one to thee, thou hadst called me ass.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Ass unawares may prove a wise man, better considered of.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.l: Ah, she begins to balance me.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: I do indeed sir.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.l: And how do you find me now?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Full weight sir.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.l: O, in good time, we shall agree anon. —
The Duke —
sp.stage: Enter Duke, with Raymond and the train.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Through the general love our subjects bear to
We find my lord your loyalty to us: (You,
Which relisheth more sweeter to our ears,
In their applauses told, then by your own.
And gentlemen I thank you every one;
You have taken much pains t'see a growing prince,
Not seasoned yet with time to your desires:
But crowned with your loves in the diadem,
I steadily shall hold the sceptre out,
While justice shall stand by me, and direct it.
I hope you will not look that I shall reign
In my first year, as your last Duke my father
In his last: but give my youth some liberty
To play the wanton prince, though not the wild one.
I have I know possessed all you that know it,
With that conceit, when I gave command,
Upon the first sight of a pair of lasses,
That have looks like the place where they were bred,
Cheerful and innocent to be brought to me,
That I may see their pleasing eyes again;
For methought on the sudden they were fair ones.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: I wonot cross your grace, but if my counsel —

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: I prithee keep it, I have no need of it,
Do not confine me, though I be your guest:
I know it may breed laughter, perhaps sorrow
Unto some grave ones, but I shall deceive 'em;
I will see 'em, and have parley with 'em:
There's no hurt meant if you mean not any,
Nor shall this wrong your house; therefore produce them.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: They are here my lord.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Udfoot, what will the young Duke do trow?
Shall we have it set down in our chronicles,
Inprimis, a brace of milkmaids? very good.
Where are our ladies now? they are to seek,
And must begin again to learn short curtsies,
And dance after the country hornpipe ▪

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Can there be any loss of royalty,
To bid these welcome? If here be any rudeness,
Let me be tasked with it, that like such rudeness?
If blood or beauty ever made a lady,
Why are not these so? I profess that man
A traitor, does not think it: yet they are still
Themselves, and so am I. Are you not sisters?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: In quality, an't shall please you;
Yet there may be a doubt the tother way,
For our fathers were next neighbours.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: That's a plaguy wench; she has not milked so many kine for nothing, she knows the danger of the horn.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: I beseech your majesty let us depart, these fine men flout us.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Well said innocence, thou art at home, and play'st within doors, the to there is more open.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: We mean no harm, an't please you: if my lord will spare us a little of his sour beer, we'll make you a dainty syllabub; that's our quality.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Udfoot, we shall be whipped anon for this abuse.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: I warrant thee wench, hold up, I'll take too lashes for thy one.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Indeed you are better able to bear it.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: What's the Duke's purpose trow? how he does eye 'em. They'd be good merchandise for some of us, now we are far from our mistresses.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: And may be so when he has done with 'em,
That's my comfort.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: What was your father?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: A swineherd if it please you.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: What yours?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: A ditcher an't shall like you.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: She's the better descended of the two.
What'll all this come to?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: If thou hadst been my sister,
And thou daughter unto some bordering prince,
As Florence, Padua, Verona, or some farther place.
What prince would not have sought and sued to you?
But go and make the habitation
Where you were born, and dwell, a paradise,
And let all courts be wild and desolate.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Excellent: my fortune's come about,
And I will venture, though my life lie on't.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: My life lies on it too.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Hold thy tongue, thou art a sharer,
As I give thee example, follow. Pardon, pardon,
Great prince, if we have through our ignorance,
Or folly, give it what name you please,
Wronged this fair presence, wronged you the light.
That came but as the Egyptians, to adore
The rising sun, and to fall down before it.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: What whirl's this?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: We are poor gentlewomen of this country.
Neighbours unto this place, that took upon us
This habit, to be freer and more bold.
And yet more harmless, fearing to be pressed
With the court compliment, that plays so thick
In a young damsels ears, it often bears
and batters down poor virgin's chastity.
We did presume upon our strength, t'withstand
The pages, footmen, and the scullery:
But when a lord should take us unto task,
Or others of your brave embroidered train,
Alas we had been like the silly fowl
Under the towering hawk, laid flat before 'em,
Upon the very shaking of their feathers.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: A good wench i'faith, she flouts them to their faces.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: But what is this intended for trow; a pastoral, or a comedy?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: A comedy sure, there's so much wit in't.
'Tis your daughter —

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Yes: but pray be silent, let's see the effect,
I dare not own her yet.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: I let ye kneel thus long, to hear again
That most harmonious voice, and ere thou risest,
Ask something of me, fit for thee to crave,
And me to give, and thou art mistress of it.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: I shall my gracious lord, I crave your pardon.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Pish, that is needless, for thou'st not offended;
Or if thou hadst, it were a poor one, that,
For I do give't to thieves and murderers:
Ask me a gift, that time may talk of it,
Being my first bounty, which I would confer
Bravely and worthily, and thou art born for't.
Hadst thou birth equal unto wit and beauty,
Thou wert a wife for any prince in Europe,
And I myself would take thee to my bed:
But rise, and think, consider what thou askest;
Yet thou art wise enough, I need not teach thee.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: How now — your haste?

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.l: Where is my lord the Duke?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Your business?

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.l: The good old Earl of — is deceased,
And the earldom now conferred unto your crown.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: 'Tis some addition; but would he still had lived
To have kept it still, he was so true a friend. —
Hast thou thought yet?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Yes my lord, I thank this messenger.
There is an earldom now fallen to your crown.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: There is.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Then that it is I crave, for him I owe
All duty, all respect, and life unto.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: What's he?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: One not far off; my father.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Is he thy father?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Yes my dread sovereign; I beseech your pardon,
The wench I think is frantic.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Hadst not thou been her father, thou hadst been so,
To have uttered such a thought. Rise up Earl of —
Thou hast thy prince's word for't.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: Have I broke my brains, as these white hairs
Do witness, for the safety of you,
And of your father before you, and the state,
To have a private gentleman, my neighbour,
Merely for getting of a handsome wench,
Raised above me — it will not be digested,
For I will break the neck of these new fortunes,
Or they shall mine, and crush me, into nothing.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Not any one beside myself beholds
The beauty of this face, where two suns move,
kindling new fires to the god of love.
The title of a Queen much better would
Become thee, than a beggar. Why didst not ask
To be what nature did intend thee for,
And I would consummate, had not fortune set thee
So many steps below me in thy birth?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: If I might not offend my gracious prince,
I would make bold to speak.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: I did and do entreat thee.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: And speak freely?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: With all liberty.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: I may I hope, without your courtier's scorn,
Pronounce myself a lady; and before
This honour was conferred upon me by you,
There did run generous blood within these veins,
And if not noble: but say there did not,
And I had been born the last of the last
Rank of basest people; yet you have made me
(Such is the power of princes) truly noble:
I am the daughter of an Earl, which is a prince,
And by that title challenge alliance
With every other prince of higher blood.
And if the emperor himself were here,
He now would own me for his kinswoman,
For I stand in the line of royalty:
And who denies it, knows not heraldry.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: Here's a wench knows how to blaze a coat.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Therefore my lord, my blood can be no let,
(If I fail not in other parts) to make
A Duchess, or a Queen, and may become
(If you be pleased to make me so) your wife,
Ambitious of your love, not of the title.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Famine and war's plague my dominions,
And strike at my own person, but I love thee,
Infinitely love thee, love thee beyond the word,
Beyond all action that expresseth it.
To call thee fair, sweet, loving, and my wife,
Are but poor attributes: thou art my soul,
The better part, that governs my best thoughts,
And bids me think on heaven, and view thee.
Thy freeness and thy wit, for such as do
Respect a dower, are sufficient.
What are towns, countries, that may be destroyed
By sword or fire, comparable to thee,
That bearest about thee in one limb the beauty
Of twenty thousand cities, and their wealth?
Thou art all the world to me, for I can live
And sit down by thee with content of mind,
Without ambition how to conquer farther,
And think I have enough; and so shall all,
All of you here, that will be counted subjects,
And wish the quiet of your sovereign:
For him that does not, let him leave me now,
And I will curse him back again a traitor;
And she herself shall curse him, and so damn him.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Nay, an't be come to that pass, I am silent.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: 'Tis best so, when the tongue may forfeit the head: I have a conned speech already; long live the Duchess.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: I am glad my lord was meal-mouthed when she was a milkmaid, I am sure he gave her no ill language.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: What princes of the East, or of the world,
When they shall see thy picture, and me by thee,
circling thee thus, and thy arms so with mine,the Duke embraceth Dorigene.
To show consent in our affections,
But will consider with himself, how poor
(Although he have the Indies in his reach)
He is to me, and sigh himself to death?
Father be merry, and my lord be you so;
For now your house is happy, and shall look
More glorious than our palaces: although
You left the walls as naked as your roof,
Let every room be decked with countenances
Cheerful, as at the hour I was born,
Whenas I heard my father was here with you,
And had the glad news brought him. Wast not so?

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: Yes, my good lord.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Why so then: music, and some wine,
That I may drink a health to her I love,
Deep as my affections.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: You shall see he will be drunk with wine
As well as with love.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: First you shall pledge me, than it shall go round,
Unless it stop at any discontent,
Whom out of all this number I would note.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: An't be good wine, it shall never stick at me, whate'er the health be.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: No, signior; I thought you had had a small-beer stomach.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.l: Never but i'th' morning.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: My lord —drinks to Raymond.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: The courtiers begin to melt, and my mighty madam knows how to command: I wonder what I shall be? The dice went equally once in my own opinion for Duchess; but Duchess mate, that's my comfort.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: What eye now looks on thee, that not contemns
The colours of the lily and the rose,
Which come as short of beauty as of sweetness?
Lend me thy hand my joy, for I will yet
But borrow it, till with thy heart I take it
At the temple, and make it mine for ever;
That fame may through the world my mind discover,
Less happy being a Duke, then being a lover.

sp.stage: Enter Bernard disguised like a doctor, Landoff his tutor like a servingman.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Come Asmody, thou seest I am ruled by thee, I take thy advice; and how dost thou like me in this doctor's habit?

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: Why very well sir, and handsome, you look as if you had travelled for your degree: but 'tis the better, for no experience is gotten without travail.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: But what shall I do, when they bring me their brittle pisspots? I cannot cast 'em.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.l: No: then give them me, I can.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Why, art thou skilful in physic?

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.l: Enough to cast away an urinal, or two.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Cast it away; I marry Asmody, so can I.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: Why and that's sufficient. If it be troubled water, let 'em carry it home again to make lie with, 'twill save soap: but you must know sir you must be reserved, and not a public professor, like your tutor.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: As little as thou wilt, Asmody.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p:
If it please you sir, you may take away the first part of my name, it does not sound so well in a servingman,
because he is always at the heels of his master.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: What, thou wouldst have as taken away, and be called Modie?

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: For your good sir I wish it, and for brevity's sake: besides sir, you hannot one scholar amongst twenty, but knows what Asmody is.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Thou say'st well: then henceforward moody, let as go to the spirit.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.l: I sir, for I am now you know your familiar.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: And a witty one, methinks .

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: I must be so for I should have a sad master of you else. And look you sir, because you sha'not prove me a liar, here is your sweethearts brother (In time of yore your chamber-fellow) in a worser pickle than you, for he is in love auriumtenus, you are but up to the middle.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: Why, I tell thee my sister is such a wild cat, there is not her fellow again in all Germany, and yet thy sister follows well after; they are a couple, and so is the devil and the hangman, and as good company: they'll flout any man under the cope; they would laugh at me, but that they know I care not for't, and put 'em out with an excellent trick that I have, called borrowing of money. Come, bear up man, and drink, look you, here's mine host come to bid us welcome.
How now mine host, what time of day is't with you, ha?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Full tide gentlemen, full tide. But you are welcome; I am your servant, your slave, your cat, or your dog, or any thing in rerum natura.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: Ha mine host, is't come to that point?
sp.p: Go thy ways, go sleep, and send thy dromedaries in with wine, and glasses clear as crystal.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: As clear as Claridiana, my brave bullies.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: What in history, mine host?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: And in poetry too, when I am pleased to couple — some wine you knaves, some wine.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: Your legs couple ill-favouredly, mine host.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: My legs were not brought up to it.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: By your leave mine host.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Welcome of this side too my man of knowledge, I am thy slave, thy servant, dog, or cat, or any thing in rerum natura.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: By your leave gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: You are welcome sir.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: I am a stranger here, and understand
You are gentlemen of this country, well descended,
And I do want such good acquaintances,
Therefore make bold to press into your company.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: An Italian sir, I take it.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Yes sir, and a small practiser in physic.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: O sir, let not your modesty wrong you,
I would you had a pill to purge melancholy,
Here's a gentleman much offended with't;
Give him a glass of claret, you are a stranger,
And he will not refuse you.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: That I will sir. — fellow, some wine. —
Sir —

sp.speaker: Doril.
sp.l: I cry you mercy.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: I drink this to your health, and I have brought it.

sp.speaker: Doril.
sp.l: How sir?

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: Let him drink off his wine, and he'll tell you more.

sp.speaker: Doril.
sp.l: You spoke something like comfort, sir.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: I did, and will persever.

sp.speaker: Doril.
sp.l: You are a welcome man, pray show how.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: Drink off your wine, and he'll show you how.

sp.speaker: Doril.
sp.l: Prithee away.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Pray sir pledge me.

sp.speaker: Doril.
sp.l: I will pledge you.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: Did you not drink two, sir?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Yes marry did he, if I have two eyes, he drunk two.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: Prithee mine host stand aside, thou hast never an eye.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: How, never an eye? that goes hard, if I have drunk out two eyes in three hours.

sp.speaker: Doril.
sp.l: Now sir will you speak?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Yes sir, and tell you what I know, although a stranger, and till this hour never saw your face.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: O villain, they were bedfellows together for a twelvemonth.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: You are in love with fair Dorigene, sister unto this gentleman.

sp.speaker: Doril.
sp.l: You amaze me.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: 'Tis true, sir.

sp.speaker: Doril.
sp.l: Yes very true I find it: but for the cure of this?

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: Why 'tis ordinary, get her good will, and lie with her. How think sir, is not that the cure?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: A better cannot be applied, I'll assure you.

sp.speaker: Doril.
sp.l: Would thou wert gone.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p:
How do you mean, in drink? give me some wine, I had forgotten myself. Mine host, I would drink
to thee, but thou art not able to pledge me: therefore here's to thee honest bluecoat.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.l: I thank you sir.

sp.speaker: Smirke.
sp.l: By your leave gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: What smirk? welcome, what wind drove thee hither?

sp.speaker: Smirke.
sp.p: The best in the four quarters: look you, here's cash, gold and silver, you must pay your debts, purchase new clothes, and come to court instantly. Your father is made an Earl, your sister a Duchess, and you are a count, or I know not what; and I am an esquire: my boy is a gentleman, when I have him, as I am laying about for one.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: The fellow has broken open some goldsmith's house, and will be hanged: dost thou know what thou dost?

sp.speaker: Smi.
sp.p: My lord, as i' am a gentleman and an esquire, I do reverence the very invention of your honour's next suit: I'll help you to a draper shall give you all your men-liveries, to make it of cloth; my haberdasher has a new block, and will find me and all my generation in bevers as long as we last, for the first handsel.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: The fellow is mad.

sp.speaker: Smi.
sp.p: Mad, or mad not, 'tis all one, I speak truth; your father's an Earl, your sister's a Duchess, you are a count, or I know not what, I am an esquire, and my boy is a gentleman, when I have him.

sp.speaker: Doril.
sp.l: What does this fellow talk?

sp.speaker: Smir.
sp.p:
This fellow talks as he thinks, and thinks as he talks, and talks what he knows. I wonot repeat it over again, for the disparagement of my wit: but
what I say, I will maintain, what I maintain, I will say; and the very bells themselves shall ring it out probatum.

sp.speaker: Drawer.
sp.p: 'Tis true indeed my lord, your sister's made Duchess of — and shall be married unto the Duke. The news doth come to town with every man, and no man disagrees, but constantly affirms it for a truth.

sp.speaker: Doril.
sp.l: O that it were so; by my father's soul
I would be free as that is, and as happy,
For I would laugh this woman from my heart,
And she should be no more to me, than her I know not,
I would be so much man, and something more:
For I would wish to enjoy her as a man,
Lose her in mind, and find her in my blood,
And I do feel such turnings in my thoughts.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: Why now you are yourself: yet I'd advise you to go to court, and see her.

sp.speaker: Doril.
sp.l: See her, I and speak to her, and call her woman,
There were no treason in't, were it?

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: Not any.

sp.speaker: Doril.
sp.p: Good; then let us go: for what I'll do till I come there, I know not, or if I did, I would not utter it.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Why Asmody, will you be found an ignorant spirit? how hap I knew not this?

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.l: You employed not me to inquire of it.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: Gentlemen, as I understand myself, I am a lord,
I do not know, I may be an abused coxcomb;
But howsoever, here are good tokens of it.
sp.p: Mine host, what have I chalked in sundry and several times?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Chalk is but chalk, a rundle makes a shilling, but that's nothing.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: I'll come to you mine host when you are sober.
Gentlemen, you are for the court,
I am for the tailors: when next we meet,
We will bring hearts as sound as our clothes, sweet.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: What, is the Duke married?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Questionless, by this time; they were at to have and to hold when I leave 'em. Look you, here come the feathers, the inseparable coxcombs of the court.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.l: By the lifeblood which danceth on her lip,
She is all paradise; divine, angelical,
The Duchess methinks looks like a dowdy to her.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: O for an informer — capital treason.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: If my tailor had not been a knave —

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: He had been an honest man.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: But —

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: O there's a stop, I thought the brazen image would ha' spoke.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Asmody, you were best stay behind,
There's no place for spirits i'th' court.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.l: O sir, all your brave spirits keep at court,
And I know my distance.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: If you do not, here be those will teach you.
What comfort man? there is no fitter place
to attend their coming out, then here,
Here you may have full sight, and perhaps speech.

sp.speaker: Doril.
sp.l: Nay I will have speech with her, and tell her roundly
How she has played the murderess with a man
That would have died most willingly for her.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: What, in the passionate vain again?

sp.speaker: Doril.
sp.l: No, but somewhat vehement.
sp.stage: Enter the Duke, Duchess, a Bishop, lord Raymond.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: The diadem that crowned my head, brought
Cares along with dignity: but thou my sweet
Hast crowned my heart with joys perpetual,
Love, that did lead thee to the church a maid,
Hath brought thee back again a perfect wife,
And made thee fit to be as thou dost promise,
Mother of many princes.
sp.stage: Dorilus kneels as the Duchess passeth by, she beckons one to bring him to her.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Pray heaven the Duke be in his right senses,
He talks all raptures, studied poetry.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: As every outrageous lover does. If I were weary of my life, I have an adagy would hang me instantly.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: What's that?
sp.stage: The Duchess and Doril. talk priuatly.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Why the old one, hot love's soon cold.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: To require you, that breath were better kept, to cool your porridge.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: You say very right, sir.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: This is the face that would not let me rest,
But visit me in dreams: look this way still,
And burn me with thy comfortable beams.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: I must confess, I ever had a wild,
Wanton, and untamed tongue, but still the heart
Of such a matron as my mother was:
I did and do still love thee, and I protest
purposed to have married thee, but that I think
Thyself would not have wished me to have lost
A fortune such as this — little did I imagine,
When I did jest those words, to have been a Duchess.

sp.speaker: Doril.
sp.l: I do not come to task you to your word,
But to behold the riches I have lost,
That must confess myself unworthy of you.
Hither I came resolved, to let you know
That I durst look upon you, and could lose you
Without sigh or tear: but having seen you,
You have afresh kindled the fire again,
And I must die a martyr in your love.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: What shall we do Julia? Dost thou see
The sad and downcast countenance of thy brother?
I love him for his own sake, and for thine,
And would not have him perish; which I fear.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Troth madam I doubt him too: but if the worst come to the worst, 'tis but a foolish lover cast away.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: There are some flattering ways yet to restore him, if we could light on 'em. Alas good Dorilus.
sp.l: I never yet had other testimony
Of your strong love, then that which all you men
Unto your ends can feign better than women,
Sighs and sad words, mingled with some tears.

sp.speaker: Doril.
sp.l: If those had not been witnesses sufficient,
Why did you not enjoin me to a task,
Harder than ever cruelty did yet?
You should ha' said; I dare thee Dorilus
To die: or do but say so yet,
That I may be assured you can love
Dorilus dead, whom living you despised,
And I will at your feet yield my latest breath.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: I prithee think me not a murderess,
To take delight in blood: no, my dear Dorilus,
Live, and live long, that I may love thee so.
Yet if thy love be, as thou dost profess,
No danger, travail, nothing that art. Can do,
Obtained with much loss, greater difficulty,
Will be left unattempted: therefore, to try
What strength it holds in thee, and make it gained,
Better esteemed of, being hardly got,
I shall enjoin thee to a strange design.

sp.speaker: Doril.
sp.l: Let it be dangerous, and 'tis the better,
And I shall easilier accomplish it.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: It is not dangerous, nor impossible,
For I have read even in effect the like
To have been obtained for a — Queen.

sp.speaker: Doril.
sp.l: Pray speak it.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: A garland of the rarest flowers on earth,
The choicest to the eye, and to the sent,
Set with such fruits the season of the year
Affords not in this clime, and it must have
The virtue of continuing ever fresh,
As long as you remain constant in love.
This is the task, which if you can obtain.
By all the faith in woman, and that justice
Which punisheth all perjurers, I vow
Thou shalt embrace all thy desires in me.

sp.speaker: Doril.
sp.l: A garland of all flowers?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Of all the earth produceth, that are choice:
If I, or any one that sees it, can
Call any flower by a name, not there,
You not perform your enterprise.

sp.speaker: Doril.
sp.l: This is a task indeed.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: She has sent you a picking.

sp.speaker: Doril.
sp.p: But it is nothing, when the prize is thought of that it shall purchase.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Will you undertake it?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: I will not move in any other labour,
It shall be both my business and my pleasures:
With my best duty let me kiss your hands.
I shall not need to doubt, to enjoy your love
When I have done it?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: May that beauty which you adore in me,
Be blasted, but —

sp.speaker: Doril.
sp.l: I believe you: fair farewell.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: My lord, your pardon.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: For what my Duchess? Though this day alone
Should be reserved only to ourselves,
Yet if thou please to lend thy patience
To any one that is a suitor to thee,
It shall give no dislike but rather please us.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Here's a Duke now will make all his subjects kind husbands.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: If he continue as he begins, I'll give my wife the breeches; for women will reign, that's certain.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Reign, I and thunder and lighten too, I'll warrant thee.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.l: A pretty dumb show, this.

sp.speaker: Doril.
sp.p: How do you sir? you appear to me more troubled than myself.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: No, I am well: pray what's the news?

sp.speaker: Doril.
sp.l: I must go travail.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Travaile, what to do?

sp.speaker: Doril.
sp.l: To gather flowers, strawberries —

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.l: And cream.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Why how now sirrah?

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.l: Something bold sir, for affinities sake.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: But pray be serious with me: by that friendship, which for the time we have been acquainted, hath been as much as ever was made up in so few hours; I do conjure you tell me, and tell me faithfully, all the whole passage.

sp.speaker: Doril.
sp.p: I was a telling you: she has enjoined me to bring her a fair garland, of all flowers that can be named, which must continue fresh as long as I remain constant to her.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: This is not in the power of man to do.

sp.speaker: Doril.
sp.l: This is her imposition.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Asmodie, what think you of this?

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.l: Why I say sir, comfort your friend, for ere
The sun shall twice to th'sea decline his golden beams
I'll bring a garland hither, made of all flowers
That every corner of the world contains,
And with that charm too, that it shall remain
Beauteously flourishing, while he continues
Warmed in the strength of his affections.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Do this my gentle spirit, and thou shalt
Make him, who is thy master, bound unto thee,
He shall release thee, I will buy thy years,
Although it cost me half of my estate.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: No more, some few hours hence expect me.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Sir, will you take the counsel of a friend,
And thrust these sorrows from you? what would you give
To purchase such a garland as you speak of?

sp.speaker: Doril.
sp.l: I thought you sir of more humanity,
And better breeding, than to mock misery.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: I do not mock you, and may accuse you now
For having me in such suspicion:
we are but young in our acquaintances,
And that begets these doubts: will you impart
Half your estate to him should bring you this?

sp.speaker: Doril.
sp.l: All, and become in debt to pay that man.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: What do you judge your estate to be, sir?

sp.speaker: Doril.
sp.l: Better then three hundred pound a year.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Why that shall do it. Pardon me sir, I am poor,
And such an accident as this perhaps,
To make a fortune, will not in all my age
Befall again: nor can you lose by it,
For in her favours you shall be advanced.

sp.speaker: Doril.
sp.l: Without those wise considerations,
You instantly shall have it made to you,
Not in words only, but in deeds,
If you perform what you propose to me.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Why you say well sir, will you now to the scriveners?

sp.speaker: Doril.
sp.l: Most joyfully, and with what speed you please.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Lead sir, I'll follow: is it not strange to see,
That a man should, as hath been often shown,
Cure others griefs, yet cannot help his own.

sp.stage: Enter Lodwick, father to Dorigene; Frederick, a lady, and Smirke.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Now sir, you are so died i'the grape, and so debauched
With tavern quarrels, that here your carriage
Amongst the inferior sort will prove ridiculous:
For we shall have you down i'the wine-cellar,
Or at the beer amongst the guard carousing,
And after, fall to cuffs; your band and doublet
Torn from your neck and back, and your brave breeches
Stained with the variation of each soil.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: Nay good sir do not aggravate a fault:
I know I have been often i'the dirt,
(And so has many a better man than I)
Before I was the Duke's brother; but now
I will give no man place at wall or kennel.

sp.speaker: Smi.
sp.l: My young lord is in my mind to a thread for that.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: I know thou hast matter enough in thee,
And parts sufficient to make a courtier;
But this same drink, and country liberty,
Has spoiled thee irrecoverably.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: Why sir, what would you ha' me do? you shall find I will be capable.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Why you must bend yourself unto the ladies.

sp.speaker: Smi.
sp.l: Bend to the ladies: alas poor old man, he talks —

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: I mean, apply yourself, converse with 'em,
And still be tendering your service to 'em;
They will look for't: look you, here come presidents;
There's a young lord now, a knight follows him,
Mark but how they endeavour in the business.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: Udsfoot, I think my father thinks I am an ass:
Cannot I lead a lady by the arm,
Hold off my hat, and dance my cinque a pace;
And after a long story of my silence,
Ask how she does? I will satisfy him,
He sha'not find me to degenerate —
By your leave lady.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: What's he trow? he has reasonable handsome clothes, but they become him not.

sp.speaker: Smir.
sp.p: The dumb lord's frighted, his hair stands an end.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.l: My noble lord; the Duchess brother.

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.l: Your pardon my good lord.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: What masculine baboon's this — lady, I honour you.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: O my good lord, there are better faces i'the court for you to honour.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: By that all-killing eye, that murdering lip —

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Fie, fie, my lord, you make me blush.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: O madam, do not so, you'll spoil your painting.

sp.speaker: Smi.
sp.l: Look you my lord, my lord your son is at it.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: A shrewd boy: I thought, because myself
Have been bred up a soldier, and unfit,
And ever was, to these court compliments;
He, having not been exercised, would be so:
I'll leave him now, and take no more charge of him.

sp.speaker: Smi.
sp.l: No, no, let the surgeon look to him.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Would I were i'the country again, I shall run mad here: your tumultuous courtiers wonot let me rest; visitants early and late, and all come about one business, to tell me I am fair, which I know well enough, yet can be well content to let them swear it. I have the prayers of all the mercers, tailors, haberdashers, i'the whole city, and their wife's curses; for not a man looks that way: I am the bird, at which each well-drawn courtier shoots his bolt. Look you, I am spied already: they leave all companies, all places; upon service times, the chapel, if I be not there.
Now my tongue-tied lord, whose language is i'the motion of his neck, I wonder he is not troubled with the crick: what does your lordship say? I do not hear you.

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.l: Hum.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Would the world believe there were such a man?
Pray my lord tell me your meaning?

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.l: Hum.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Sure your honour had a silent nurse.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: He would ha' proved the miracle of the world, if he had been a woman.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: He would indeed signior: I do not think, but if his tongue were clipped, he would talk yet; what think you?

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.l: I think as you think, lady.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Take heed of that, so you may wrong yourself.
I would my lord that I could understand you,
I do persuade myself then I could love you.

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.l: O sweet lady.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Why this is well my lord, can you go on?

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.l: I had a hard heart else.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Admirable; good my lord go forward,
Talk, and I'll love you infinitely, that is, beyond talk.

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.l: Silence lady is the best part of wisdom.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Let wisdom go to grave ones, give us talk,
It is youth's music, and doth stir affection,
As motion, heat. Good my lord talk.

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.l: Why lady, I can talk.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: O my lord.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: What ail you, lady?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: You will ravish me.

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.l: Not I, I'll assure you I come not of the kind.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: I mean you'll overcome me: and if you talk much, I shall entreat you you will hold your peace.

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.p: Nay, believe it lady, I will not talk much: but if I list to talk, I have a tongue that can talk much, and loud, as another man.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.l: I was afraid he would ha' said, woman.

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.p:
But talk's but talk, therefore I use it not: but for your sake, sweet lady, it may be that I will find a tongue
to talk of something; and that same something must be of you, or else 'tis nothing.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Away my lord, I am bound to stop mine ears; the Syrens sing in you.

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.p: Why let 'em sing, song is but song, no more then talk's but talk; yet talk does well, where talk is well regarded, otherwise 'tis lost: and I have been a talker in my time, and will be so again, to give content to such a lady as doth love to talk, or knows what talk is, and can talk herself; else 'tis much better for to hold ones peace: for I have heretofore been a great talker, and foolish ladies that understood me not, have prayed me hold my peace, and they would love me; just as you now, on the contrary, pray me to talk, and not to hold my peace, and then you'd love me.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: I will maintain this in him, to make him talk his lungs our. — o, — oh.

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.l: What is the matter?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Would I had never heard this tongue of yours:
But I was cursed to hear it, more to provoke it.

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.p: Why do you say so? For this tongue of mine shall be pulled out, and thrown unto the dogs, or to the hawks, before it shall offend your dainty ears, that love to hear a tongue talk as a tongue should do, of wit and beauty, and beauty and wit, which do abound in you.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Fie, fie, fie, this is not to be endured.

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.p:
Believe it lady, but it is; 'tis fit that you should hear, and I should talk, the subject being you, and I the talker. Wherefore have ladies beauty, and men eyes and tongues, but to behold that beauty, and then talk of it. I do proclaim him here a dunce, a sot,
that has a tongue, and cannot talk of you: nay, though he had never a tongue, yet he might think a talk; and that, though not as good, might serve for talk.
sp.stage: Enter lord Raymond and the Duchess.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: The Duchess; good my lord leave until another time.

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.p: Ay, another time, and then we'll talk four or five hours together.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: By this hand wench I'll keep touch.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Touch and take my lord, else no meddling.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: Go, you are a fool, farewell; expect me.
sp.p: Sister Duchess, how dost? I thank thee for my lordship. I knew thou wert born to make us all, advance us to the third region. How does my brother Duke deal with thee? Dost thou burgeon? Shall we have bonfires, and the bells rung out, for joy thou hast made an uncle? How now Julia? what's thy title? Lady of honour, and principal secretary to my sister, is't not? who breaks the best jests now?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: My lord.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: My lord; no, my lady by all means.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Fie brother, understand yourself; and as you have taken on dignity, so put on gravity, or you will prove ridiculous.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: Let me prove what I will sister, I'll have all the court to imitate me: if I had been born a fool, I wonder what's he would ha' been wise? Come wench, be thyself still, and thou shalt be the miracle of princes,
sp.l: Have all the wit thy subjects utter, thine,
And drawn together in a volume, called,
The Duchess of Saxony her apothegms;
Which shall put down the tales of other nations.
Thy birthday shall be made a holiday,
And crowned with full cups, and with deep ones too,
And I myself will first begin the health,
And bring it up in Germany a fashion,
Oft to salute the cup, and kiss it sweetly.
But where's the Duke my brother? tired and retired?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Pray my lord do you speak to him, happily he will endure reproof from you.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: My lord.

sp.speaker: ●re.
sp.p: I have sworn not to grant any suits this week, therefore prithee do not trouble me — — oh, my lord, I cry you mercy.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: The Duchess would be private.

sp.speaker: ●re.
sp.l: Neat and private she shall be, 'tis fit,
Let you and I shake hands, wisdom and wit.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Thou art all wildness, that nothing I think will tame, but a long voyage, and unfortunate.
O Julia, I do think upon thy poor afflicted brother, good gentleman, that he should place his love so disastrously. I wonder how he does?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: He is as great a stranger unto me as to you madam, I never saw him since.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: I hope he did not spend his time so ill
In the university at Wittenberg,
But he has learned so much philosophy,
To tame those headstrong passions.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: You may pray rather he has not spent his time
As Faustus did, and many that are there,
In negromancie, so to perform the task
You have laid on him.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Alas poor wench, dost thou believe there can be such an art?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Why, have we it not recorded, Faustus did
Fetch Bruno's wife, Duchess of Saxony
In the dead time of winter, grapes she longed for?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Such a report there goes, but I hold fabulous.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Well, had I been as you, I'd not ha' laid so deep an oath upon't.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Would that were my worst fear. Enter Doril.look where he comes. Julia leave me, I'll hold conference with him, and by delays seek to wear out his sorrow.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I obey you madam.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Why kneel you Dorilus?

sp.speaker: Doril.
sp.l: Duty has taught me, though you were not her
Fortune has made you: every thing delights
To be commanded by you; under your wish
Lies all things upon earth, and grows for you,
Prospers for your sake, strives to be lovely,
In emulation of your excellence.
Here is a garland of those flowers you spoke of,
Which nature put forth, and art fetched for you;
Place it upon your head, and it shall dim
The glorious splendour of your other crown:
Lasting it is, as it; for it shall flourish
According to your wishes, till I alter
And change the course of my affection.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Thou dost astonish me: would I could call
This any thing but truth, a dream, a vision,
With terrors following it, enough to sink me
Deeper in earth than I am now above it.
When Flora strives to deck the earth with flowers,
She never showed half such variety.
Good Dorilus leave me a while to think,
and to collect myself, and then return.

sp.speaker: Doril.
sp.l: I shall.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Why did these flowers grow? to blush for me?
Or do they blush, because they have wrought my shame?
Why did not storms and North winds nip your buds,
And killed ye, ere you showed the sun your leaves?
Why did not lightnings blast ye? Beasts or worms
Pluck up your roots, and make you fit for fire?
There you had showed more glorious than here:
For here you bring, under so many colours,
A show of sweetness, that will breed the plague,
And run infectiously into our bloods.
For if I fall, what woman will be honest?
Or being so, what's he that will believe it?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: How now my Duchess? talking to thyself?
What's that? Why dost thou hide it from me?
It is rich unto the eye, but much more rarer:
Flowers so plentiful, and at this time,
It wonders me? Prithee let me see it,
I never saw so many various forms
Knit up so curious: believe me, 'tis a present
Fit for the Queen of nations, and for thee;
He well deserved, that did bestow it on thee.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: 'Tis not to be bestowed sir, 'tis to be bought,
And at a dear rate too.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Why, and thou dost, no matter,
For trust me 'tis a very pretty toy.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: A pretty toy must buy it.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: If it would not fade.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: It will not fade sir, it will keep too long I fear, for you to like it.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Why dost thou think so? it is like thyself,
Full of variety, and choice delights,
And th'longer I behold it, the more it likes me.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: O, there are serpents in't, and ugly toads,
That burst and shed their poison; not a flower,
But bears a sting in it, that wounds my heart:
Foul lust and murder, that doth follow it,
Lies hid amongst the leaves. O throw me sir,
Throw me from your embraces, as far as the wild winds
Doth drive the dust before it, and destroy me.
Like it to nothing: purge your land, by making
Bonfires of it and me upon some hill,
That the black smoke may vanish into air.
And not infect your turrets.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Why dost thou talk thus?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: First kill me sir, it will be charity,
Then rip my bosom up, and in my heart
There you shall find what my tongue loathes to utter.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: I thought, dear Dorigene, I never should
Have been a stranger to your thoughts, till now:
I pry thy speak, what is it troubles thee?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: If I were sure that breath should be my last,
You should not then entreat me; but receive it,
Hoping you will be merciful, and kill me.
There is a gentleman, named Dorilus,
That loved me 'fore you saw me, and I him,
Although I never gave him any hope:
Upon the wedding day he met me here,
And looked so like a man that meant to perish,
That I was willing to restore some comfort;
Whereon I wished him get me such a garland,
Made of all flowers that the world contains,
not thinking such a thing could have been done,
And for requital promised him — I cannot
Utter no more, nor should have thought so much.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Is this all?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: All? would you more? would you we should proceed?
Grow impudent in sin, till thunder rent us?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Why, but such promises may be dispensed with.
Though you had sealed it with a vow.

sp.speaker: Doril.
sp.l: I did sir, and a great one: nor left there,
But added two or three to that; the least was,
The blasting of this beauty he adored.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: I know not how to doubt, yet this may be
A cunning; I will try her. Let it not trouble thee,
Dear Dorigene; thou shalt perform thy vow;
I'll be the sufferer, and take the sin on me.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: But the damnation must be mine, my lord,
And if I pull it on me, 'tshall be this way,
Rather then wronging you.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Why so thou wrongest me worst,
And wilt deprive me of all the joys in this world.
Thou wilt teach me by ill example, how to follow thee.
Sweet, let me kiss thee, I will beg for that,
Which all men else do labour to avoid;
It is but one hours loss of thee, I prithee
Make no more scruple of't then other women:
It is a crime, that not one night i'the year,
But somewhere or other such a fault is made,
Nor looks the wife the next day worse for it.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: No more sir.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Thou wilt consent?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: I will.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p:
Why I thank thee. I have bestowed some
pains to beg myself into an order. O Dorigene, if thou beest false, the serpent parted with his subtlety, and closed it in the fruit he gave thy sex.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: I know not whether I am greater blessed ▪
Or cursed in such a husband: fate thou hast thy ends,
And I have mine. Come Dorilus, and take me
Now whilst I have obedience:
Give me not respite, to enter into considerations,
Lest I do ▪ worse then perform my vow.
He comes — welcome my Dorilus, be merry man,
And look upon me as a lover should,
That has obtained his mistress: I am thine,
And for the time free, as I am the Dukes.
Be bold man in approaching, there's no fear
Of spies upon us; we are free, as people
That know no laws, or do command the laws:
I have the Duke's consent for what I do,
Nay, his entreaty: he does like to have
A rival in the thing he loves, and is
Not different from the common sort of men,
That do esteem them most, that most abuse 'em.

sp.speaker: Doril.
sp.l: How many ways do you desire to kill me?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Why Dorilus?

sp.speaker: Doril.
sp.l: You say the duke's acquainted —

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: With our loves, 'tis true:
But there's no harm in that, for he'll be secret,
As I have life, he will.

sp.speaker: Doril.
sp.l: Why do you abuse me thus?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: I do not: for as I have a soul, I'm serious,
He bid me keep my vow; and said, the man
That did bestow this garland, did deserve —

sp.speaker: Doril.
sp.l: What? to enjoy you?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Ay, to enjoy me.

sp.speaker: Doril.
sp.l: He did it then to give us leave to sin,
That he might punish.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: O no; he did it for my quiet: he will sooner
Strike his own eye, to offend it, nay, his heart,
Rather than mine.

sp.speaker: Doril.
sp.l: What do we then contriving lust together?
That rebel blood, which rageth against him,
Had better been bestowed upon rude beasts,
Wilder than wolves or tigers; we are worse:
They that would wrong this truly royal prince,
This prince of his own passions, as of men,
Deserve to see no day, to taste no food,
No clothes to shield him from the rage of winter,
But live more wretched than the last of beggars,
Die without tears or prayers, and want a grave.
Take your vows back again, and place 'em better,
For here I make a general release
Of all debts twixt us, be a free woman,
And set up anew, with caution, that you never
Prove bankrupt again, deal not so largely,
Nor trust so prodigally, lest you do meet
With such as will take the full forfeiture;
So virtue guard you and your goodness crown,
Your thoughts and actions with true chastity.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: This is not as I look for, nor do wish.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: O stay, let me not be so wretched, but to pay
The alms of a true heart, thanks for your bounty,
Which hath been greater than I can requite.
Now I do love thee Dorilus as dear
As thy own mistress virtue. And I beseech thee
deprive us not thy presence at the court,
For I will live to study a requital,
And the Duke with me, that shall know thy worth,
And find it in thy deeds, shall entertain thee,
And in his bosom fix thee a true friend:
Thou shalt not go unless thou promise me,
I may receive and welcome thee at court,

sp.speaker: Dori.
sp.l: Since you command me, I'll not fail to offer,
My service to my sovereign and you.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: With tears of joy I love thee.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: What blood have these two creatures? Cold as I am
My aged head wrapped like the Alps in snow,
Yet if the devil lust, had warmed me on,
Respects should never quench the heat in me.
There is a spark already in my bosom,
And I do feel it working towards my heart,
Which when it once hath reached, and kindled
Into a flame, no premeditation
Of the offence, shall blow it out again.
The Duke has entertained a jealousy,
And employs me in the discovery,
Which makes effectual to my purposes.
Mischief is brooding in my brains, and the event
Shall work my pleasures or their discontent.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Well met sir. How now? Melancholy.
But now I think on't, every man is so
After his height of dalliance, I did hear
You had admittance ▪ and i saith how find you her.

sp.speaker: Dori.
sp.l: You have my land sir.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Yes, in my pocket, a large hose you'll say
Can hold so many acres: but impart,
you told me, being familiar with the cause,
I should partake in the event.
She has performed —

sp.speaker: Doril.
sp.l: Yes, very gracious.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Why so then, what would you more?

sp.speaker: Doril.
sp.l: No more.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Zfoot, he's turned echo: but I have observed,
Knock at the heart of man after full joys,
And you shall find him like an empty vessel.
I will leave you sir.

sp.speaker: Doril.
sp.l: Hear me first.
Because you may not spread a calumny,
Which when you're not yourself, wine may bring forth:
Here I protest by all that's righteous,
Both in earth and heaven, though I had bought
And paid for this sin as yourself can witness,
And might have purchased it (But with her curses)
I gave her vows back freely to herself,
Made her the same Duchess that she was,
And is still absolute.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: How? freely gave her what cost you so dear?

sp.speaker: Doril.
sp.l: Freely: and had my life been in the bargain,
It had gone, and wife and children,
If I had been worth 'em — oh you do not know,
And it is tedious to relate it to you.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: You are a frank giver, and you shall teach me
(For in all goodness I will be your scholar)
To imitate, though not to equal you:
Here take your bonds again, if you could check
That untamed fiend, called lust, why should not I,
By your example, bridle avarice:
He is not worthy to receive, that knows not how to restore.
Pray take it, you wonot,
You would be singular, then look you sir 'tis cancelled:
Thus from the letters I do tear the law,
As you the crime you went with from your heart,
You have your own again: and I am richer
Without it, then possessing. Fare you well sir.

sp.speaker: Doril.
sp.l: Pray stay sir, and make me not so wretched
As leave that ugly sin ingratitude
For my companion: I may through your friendship
Think this life happy, to score age upon me,
And die, with storeys of you to my children.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: And I of you would do the like to mine:
That shall if I can work it, call you uncle.

sp.speaker: Doril.
sp.l: Bernard my friend, and chamber-fellow.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: And brother that would be, nay must be;
Though I undertake as bad a task as picking of flowers.
For here's my spirit Asmody can fly
The same way again.

sp.speaker: Lan,
sp.l: No, I have clipped his wings.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: 'Sfoot my tutor, I am undone.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: And bound him to a fiery chariot
For threescore years, and after to be thrown
Into the bottom of the burning lake,
Boiling with pitch and sulphur.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Alas poor Asmody, he will be over coddled,

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: For his audaciousness.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Alas sir, 'twas not his fault; for to say truth, I conjured him.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: You conjured him, into what? into a blue coat
And a beard, did you not? look you there's your Asmody.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Troth sir, you have been too cruel with him,
You might a let him have boiled in his livery,
for his herd, it was not a miss to be plucked off,
For in time it would a been scalded.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Come, you are a novice, did you think you could
Proceed in my own art, but I should know it?
I was that Asmody appeared to you,
When you kept such a thundering, with words
That were of as much effect to call or move
Spirits, as mountains: but my Dorilus,
My loving pupil, for whose good I cannot
With all the art I have, labour enough.

sp.speaker: Doril.
sp.l: O, your zeal sir hath been ever shown,

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Presume upon me, for I do predict
There will be need of me, and of my art
Ere it be long: and unless it please
My pupil Bernard, here to turn me off,
I'll e'en in to my livery again.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: You may do as you please sir, but if you do,
I shall forget you are my master, and make account
I have my servant Asmody again.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Do so, and command me as you have done,
I'll be unto your will obedient
As your own limbs, and howsoe'er things sort,
In spite of fortune we'll have a ▪ little sport.

sp.stage: Enter Duke, l. Raymond at one door: Duchess, Dorilus bore before her, leaning on his shoulder and giving much grace unto him. Music.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Sir, I have a suit to you.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Speak it.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: To know this gentleman, and if not for my sake,
for his own to grace him, he has deserved it.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: He has.
sp.stage: Dorilus kneels, the Duke draws his sword and runs it on his bosom.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: O my dear brother.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: What do you mean sir.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Away with her to prison, and let her father,
And her brother both be turned out of the court.
Lord Raymond, be it your charge to see it done.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: Unwillingly I obey you; oh my heart dances,
And tuned unto so many joys, it beats
My blood about me into every part,
That I grow young again; alas good lady,
Why do you weep? these tears were well becoming
If you had any crime to wash away,
But you are clear as heaven; then bear yourself
As confident and shining, that stands unshaken,
When men speak blasphemy and throw up curses:
Beware sweet Princess, your too zealous care,
Expressed in the behalf of your firm friend,
May be by some informing ear snatched up,
