And carried to the Duke, which would pile high,
And heighten up the mountain of his wrath.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Let it be so, and let that mountain fall,
And all the world, with his displeasure on me,
But hidden in the ruin, yet at last
It is my comfort, I shall be found myself.

sp.speaker: Ray,
sp.l: What a well built castle is a clear conscience?
No battery, no invasion stirs it,
When a guilty on, is like a spider's web,
Shook with the motion of each little fly.
What help there lies in me much injured lady,
Assure yourself of it, as if your own heart
Had the power to work it.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: I should wrong much noblesse to think otherwise.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: See madam, here's a guard upon you.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: They are welcome.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: So, the devil when he meaneth to seduce,
Puts on an angel's shape, who doth not know.
How to dissemble, must not think to grow
Or prosper in his purpose. In this plot
Envy alone is not expressed, but hot
Untameable desires, which flame so high;
One mischief must another satisfy.
I love, fair Julia, and there was no way
How to obtain, but bringing to decay
The greatness of the Princess; misery
Will burst the strongest bar of chastity.
She comes:

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Where is my wretched mistress?

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: Alas, she is lost, and those that seek her,
Must be companions of her misery.
Therefore be wise fair Julia, and forget her;
Thou art as fair as she, as excellent;
And I that rule the Duke do think so.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: What means this?

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: The meaning is like him that utters it,
Plain and sincere, to make thee mistress
Of all the happiness which thou canst wish;
As she whom I create shall stand above,
And laugh at the calamities of others:
Look not upon my hairs, I'm not so old
But I can kiss thee into action,
Infuse a breath into you through your ear,
Shall call a flaming blush into your cheek,
And turn this springtide of your tears to fire,
Or change 'em into blood, and strike 'em inward,
to incite a heat as sensual as the same
That did beget you.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I am uncapable of this ill language:
But suppose I were (My lord) as you esteem me,
Is this a time, when my heart's full of sorrow,
Ready to break for their unfortunate fates,
To give admittance to so loathed a fact,
That never could be tempted in the height
Of festivals: and all the soothing flatteries
Trust up in vows and glories of a court.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: Why? I will give you liberty to think,
To ponder on it for a little time;
For I would rather love should make thee mine
Then violence or fear. Consider of it
Without delays, return me absolute:
I am not like your dull cold Englishman,
That can attend his mistress a whole day,
A week, a month, a year, yet check his blood,
And when it should have vent to burst in fire,
He weeps out in water. The sun burns
Not outward, as my blood within, passions beat
So thick and short, they make my entrails sweat.
But for a while I leave you, think and be wise.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: 'Tis wisdom to conceal what I do think,
And truth to call thee villain: oh we are
Ruined, all of us are ruined,

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.l: Yonder she is, and weeping —
Who will not be in love with sorrow, while it takes up
Her dwelling in that face, it is a question?
Whether smiles more adorn that cheek then tears.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: O worthy sir, how does my brother?

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.l: Well, do not you fear it lady.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Why do you leave him?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: To comfort you that have more need of it,
For he sits up and laughs at misery,
With hope to out live it, which is fortitude
Fitting a noble spirit.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Fortune my foe why dost thou frown on me, etc. A good voice is a perpetual comfort to a man, he shall be sure he cannot want a trade. Yonder's madam Julia, and the Italian doctor administering, they look like a couple of tragedians in the fourth act, out of countenance. Right worshipful, charitable, most bountiful and well disposed, please you to look upon the estate of a poor decayed lord, blown out of the bosom of good fortune, unto the back side of men's bounties, from whence a sweet gale of good will may arise to blow me out of the dead sea of want and despair, into the happy haven of good harbour, where I may lie at rest from hunger and cold, bound unto you in the beadroll of benevolence, which howsoever small a pittance it shall be, in this ebb of adversity, it shall be returned treble to you again in the next tide of prosperity — sweet madam,
sp.l: Why here 'Is the right fashion of the world,
To turn the backside to a man that has no money?
They are gone to wash away grief in salt water,
I mean to drown it in good claret.
Oh courteous fortune that hath send me a companion.
Smirke, how dost thou chicken? come hold up thy head,
And let's see the dismality of thy countenance,
The doleful dumps that therein do appear,
The knobbles of adversity and fate. Hum. —

sp.speaker: Smir.
sp.l: O, oh.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: What o? Where lies the cramp?

sp.speaker: Smir.
sp.l: O, oh.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: With that the moody squire thumped his breast,
And reared his eyes to heaven for revenge.
Speak sweet Jeronimo.

sp.speaker: Smir.
sp.l: First take my tongue, and afterwards my heart.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: Good both being out, now let us have the story.

sp.speaker: Smir.
sp.l: Kicked with disgrace, and turned out of the court
Both to the guard and black guard made a sport.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: Excellent Smirke.

sp.speaker: Smi.
sp.l: To laundresses and lackeys made a scorn,
And to all other people quite for .

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: One, rhyme more, and I will crown thee Fennar Laureate.

sp.speaker: Smir.
sp.l: The carters, colliers, and the carriers cursed me
The porters pulled me, and the pages pursed me.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: Why this 'tis to be a squire Smirke before your time
And your boy to be a gentleman before you have him.

sp.speaker: Smir.
sp.p: O that I had been so happy to have lived and cleave wood i'the country, preached at the buttery bar unto the ploughman, and there have used my authority in folio, when all the servants of the house should be drunk at midnight, cum privilegio.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: Ay, those were certain days, but what wilt thou do now?

sp.speaker: Smir.
sp.p: Learn to wind whipcord, and go hang myself.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: But where didst thou leave my father?

sp.speaker: Smi.
sp.l: I left him condoling with two or three of his friends
At the sign of the lamentation.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: The salutation thou meanst.

sp.speaker: Smi.
sp.l: In the salutation one way, and the lamentation
The tother — here comes more abuse.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Methinks sirrah, since my tongue broke loose,
I take an infinite pleasure in't, how thinks thou?

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.l: Your lordship talks wondrous current,
For your word will go before many a man's bond.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: It shall run before any man's bond for a wager.
My honourable lord, how does the great Duchess,
Your sister?

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.l: And the good Earl your father.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: With the rest of your kindred and acquaintance that bore the court before 'em.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: I hope a man may court his mistress now without a patent from your honour.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: I hope a man may crack your pipkin pate,
And cut your neck of mutton into steaks,
If you will not be quiet, ye brace of wicker bottles.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.l: Wicker bottles! he calls us wicker bottles.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: I and musty ones.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: And mangy ones to, are we not?

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: Yes, every thing that's troublesome and stinks you are.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Ha, ha, prithee laugh at him.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.l: Ay, we will laugh at him, but let us go,
For the fellow is desperate, and perhaps may beat us;
Such people fear no law.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: Hang him, he dares not within the confines of the court.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.l: Ay, but we may talk ourselves out of the liberties,
And then he may beat us without the confines.
Yet if he did, 'twere all one to me, for I can
Endure a beating as well as another man,
Custome's another nature: but yet I would we were gone:

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p:
Why, come then let's go back again? For my
own part, I do not care for quarrelling there we may be bold, though my lord, I have a poor sister I would prefer to cut your honour's toes.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: And I have a project, if it please your honour, to set it on foot, it may make a great many of us ride a horseback.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: O that the place were not privileged.

sp.speaker: Smir.
sp.l: Ay, and the place were not privileged.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: Why? what wouldst thou do?

sp.speaker: Smir.
sp.l: Let 'em alone, and laugh at 'em.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: Why, gramercy Smirke, thou hast instructed me.
A my conscience I should now do so.

sp.speaker: Smir.
sp.l: Yet he he gave me a bob i'the project.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: Why? hast thou any thing to do with projects?

sp.speaker: Smi.
sp.p: Yes, I was to prefer one for putting down pigs i'the fair time.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: How? putting down pigs, pry thy let's hear that?

sp.speaker: Smi.
sp.p: Why, a fellow that will undertake to find the country people, and the people of the fair, with good repast for three pence a meal.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: How can that be? pry thy let's understand?

sp.speaker: Smir.
sp.l: Why sir, a cook will undertake to bake in a pasty
Four oxen, without butter corner wise,
Lamb and mutton in the middle,
All kind of fowl on each side,
With their bills lying out to discover their condition,
With which he will be bound to find the fair seven days,
And give thee over plus to the poor.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: This is a very pretty one and profitable.

sp.speaker: Smir.
sp.p: Then I have another, for the crying of small bear, from six i'the morning, till twelve at noon, for all that are Barnaby.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p:
A most necessary one, and had it been propounded
when I was a lord, it should have had my countenance.

sp.speaker: Smir.
sp.p: Nay, it would ha' gone forward, for all your high bloods would a countenanced it, yet it was thought there was a rich milk-woman would a crossed it, and have brought it to posset drink i'the winter, and whay i'the summer, and the apothecaries would have joined with her, to have clarified it.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: Not unlikely. But Smirke, what is your purpose?

sp.speaker: Smi.
sp.l: To stay till the good time, and take a whipping,
With as much resolution as a man may take a whipping

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: Then you look for the lash?

sp.speaker: Smir.
sp.p: I do not look for it, because it comes with a back blow, and there is no ward for it but patience.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: Why thou sayest right, and it is manly done,
Not to run from, but to meet affliction.

sp.speaker: Smir.
sp.p: Ay, but when affliction comes like a fury, with a whip in her hand, 'tis a fore matter.

sp.stage: Enter Landoffe in his study, a spirit to him.

sp.speaker: Spirit
sp.l: Leave with thy potent charms to tear th'elements
And vex the poor inhabitants: here is the ring
Transparent as the day, that makes the wearer
Lost to all sight, and walk invisible
To every eye but yours: and whensoe'er
It is your pleasure it shall lose its virtue,
Touched but with this herb and it falls in pieces.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Thanks my industrious spirit.

sp.speaker: Spirit
sp.l: What else is thy command '

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Naught else at this time, but on all occasions
Thou in a thought be ready to attend.

sp.speaker: Spirit
sp.l: I shall.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: Begun. Dorilus, Bernard come forth, all things are at peace
sp.l: As your hearts shall be ere I part from you,
At least forsake you: behold this little ring,
Purer than crystal, full of subtler flame
Than that which sparkles i'the diamond;
Of virtue infinite beyond its beauty.
With this ring Dorilus thou shalt free the Princess
At least endeavour; 'tis certainly reported
At her arraignment, as the hour comes on,
She shall have none to plead her cause for her,
But her supposed crime laid ope, and urged
Withal the mouth of law, and so condemned:
Yet thou that ever couldst speak well, without
A cause so full of matter and of truth,
Shalt hid to all eyes, by virtue of this ring,
Become an orator, and plead for her,
And make the court amazed to hear thee speak.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: You amaze me, first to hear you —

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: But I'll amaze my pupil Bernard more,
When he shall stand by thee and hear thee talk,
Yet not have power to see thee: put on this ring,
Now tell me Bernard where is Dorilus?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Into air vanished, or sunk into the earth,
For I protest I see no Dorilus.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Call to him, try if he hear thee,

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Dorilus, Dorilus.

sp.speaker: Doril.
sp.l: Why here man, I am here.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Here; where?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Why here, close by thee, now I touch thee.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: This is thy hand?

sp.speaker: Doril.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: It may be foot for any thing that I know, but that
Now I feel the fingers, thou mayst hold it up at the bar
And ne'er be burned i the hand I'll warrant thee.

sp.speaker: Doril.
sp.l: Why? I see thee plain as I did before,
And every thing else.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: But that I have confidence in my master and his art, I would never look to see thee again.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Look you Julia your mistress, comfort her,
And take the work upon you:
I'll to my blue coat again, and instantly wait on you.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: All your best wishes. Fairest.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: O sir they lie in you.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: O you speak music to the melancholy,
Health to the sick.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: For next unto the delivery of my mistress,
My brother's welfare is, which you promised.

sp.speaker: Doril.
sp.l: Why sister I am well? next under heaven
I praise this gentleman.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: That is his voice, where are you brother?

sp.speaker: Doril.
sp.l: Here sister just before you.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Before me?

sp.speaker: Doril.
sp.l: Yes, in the very mouth of you, as a man would say

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Trust me I cannot see you.

sp.speaker: Doril.
sp.p: Trust me I'm glad of it, I'll talk the bolder and and the louder, they shall hear me.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: This I perceive does somewhat trouble you.
But let it not, it shall be for a good,
Which though it cannot change, may stir your blood.
sp.p: See they are hot in preparation, and people making to behold the arraignment,

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p:
Fortune is a good housewife, she plies her wheel well
alas poor lady, I pity her; for a my conscience she is clear of the fact laid to her.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: It is the maddest world, the report goes she ●hud lie with on for a nosegay.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: In some things fame will be free I see, in some things scant; for I'll assure you 'twas for a garland.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Why a garland let it be, she had been better won it with some other dance then the old one: but she has hard measure methinks , not to be allowed an advocate; for alas, what can a woman say for herself in such a case?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Dost thou think an advocate can handle it better?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Yes, if he have a feeling of the business.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Away traitor.
sp.stage: Enter the Duke, judges, Raymond, with others, the form of a court.

sp.speaker: Judge.
sp.l: Bring forth the prisoner, place her at the bar.
sp.stage: Enter Dorigen placed at the bar.

sp.speaker: Judge.
sp.l: Read the indictment.

sp.speaker: Clarke.
sp.p:
Dorigen Ebroistene, daughter to guide ebroisten, in the province of Mysen gentleman; and by the grace and favour of our sovereign lord Duke of Saxony made Duchess, attainted of high treason, by committing adultery with one Dorilns Truohesse, a private gentleman of the same province of Mysen, who by good and sufficient witness (Beside her own shameless confession to the Duke himself) is here justly accused, and indicted of the fact; yet the Duke out of his most gracious clemency, desirous of a direct and lawful proceeding, admitteth the said dorigen — daughter to the aforesaid Guido — to answer for herself, and wisheth with all his soul (Such is his infinite affection to
her, that she could clear herself of the crime. So heaven and the justices of her cause defend her!

sp.speaker: 1 Judg.
sp.p: Speak lady, free and fearless, what can you say?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Nothing but that I do desire to die,
For it is sin enough that the Duke thinks
I am guilty of the fact, all the clemency
That you can, show me or I do desire,
Is to condemn me quickly.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: That I must speak it grieves me in a cause,
Which I cud wish never had presidence,
As it hath had too often, alas that I
Who do bleed inward, to behold this woman
Fallen by a sin equal to Lucifer.
From her clear heaven where she stood a star,
Moving in his arms as her proper orb,
That I should see this woman as I say.
Who had she been a fixed one, had never
Shot from her sphere, but as an exhalation,
Drawn by the attractive virtue of the sun,
Appears a glorious star yet wanting matter.
To maintain his lustre, shoots forth his flame:
And drops from whence it came unto a dunghill,
So was this woman raised and so she fell:
That so much beauty which was given for honour,
And did advance her to it, should cause shame,
Who can tell whether this be the first man,
That she hath sinned withal, since usually,
Many faults are committed ere one found,
She promised the fellow of her lust,
Upon condition to make that: and what was it?
A garland: a garland of all flowers,
of what effect who knows, or to what purpose,
Both being as certain as the thing itself,
How or from whence it came nay more than this;
She was so impudent to tell the Duke,
And tell him she had sworn, which the immodests,
And most professed strumpet never would:
What name of shame is to be given this woman,
That would thus lewdly suffer the wild tongue,
Prcoclaim performance of so vild a deed,
And unto him she knew did love her so,
She might perhaps by her beauty and her tears,
Or both together stir compassion,
In many here, and in the Duke himself,
But when her crime shall be remembered,
A crime so beyond mercy being done,
Unto a prince; and such a prince as he is,
What can I less inspire me all ye powers?
That thought me worthy of authority
Then without pity to condemn this woman.

sp.speaker: 1. Judg.
sp.l: The case is too apparent.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: Is it not grave fathers.

sp.speaker: 2 Judg.
sp.l: Yes indeed it is, I was almost asleep.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: Ye all do know, all ye that know the law,
Who pardoneth the offender doth commit,
An offence equal with him that doth punish,
The harmless innocent than she must die,
I grieve to speak't and am so charitable,
To wish that her reproach may die with her.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: I thank thee for the last speech, it was well,
Oh that she now cud speak and clear herself.
But proceed, give sentence, if she stay long,
And I stand by a witness of her tears,
She'll weep herself guiltless and innocent,
therefore go on.

sp.speaker: Doril.
sp.l: Stay.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Who's that?

sp.speaker: 1 Judg.
sp.l: I know not.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: Whence come that voice.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Out of the clouds I think,
For no man dares own it.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Go forward and give sentence.

sp.speaker: Doril.
sp.l: Stay I say.

sp.speaker: 1 Judg.
sp.l: It spoke again.

sp.speaker: 2 Judg.
sp.l: It came by my ear.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: The court is troubled.

sp.speaker: Doril.
sp.l: Hear me ye ministers of justice,
And thou patron of it and truth,
That comes to you for succour, and for safety.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Keep your places, for let it be the devil
I will hear him; and hearing shall determine
Whether he be a spirit of truth or lies.

sp.speaker: Doril.
sp.l: The all preserver that guards innocence,
And often lets it pine, but never perish,
Can raise a voice from stones, or trees, or winds,
To plead the cause that needs no eloquence.
What hath this lady done that here you bring her
Unto a bar of shame? It is't for being virtuous,
Because she hath been constant to her lord:
But some have called her chastity in question,
That never had a spark in their own breasts,
And have possessed the Duke from his own thoughts,
That she must needs be bad because they are so.
Has every woman so much wit to hide
That fault especially? and had not she,
Who is the mirror of of her sex for that,
More than for beauty? But she told the Duke
she had offended in an idle promise,
And that's objected to her for a crime;
A piece of impudence unparallel.
When had she meant to have wronged her royal lord,
She would have locked the secret in her heart,
And set her face with smiles, beaten with kisses
Suspicion from his bosom; but she discovered
The gift, the giver, and the vow that bought it.
Who is't not knows, dishonesty consisteth
In the deed done, not in the spoken word?
And she imagining the deed in which
She employed the doer, never to be done,
And so the wickedness. Let me not be thought tedious
Nor be offensive, if I bring to mind
The meeting of those two, how she revealed,
That you great Duke consented to the fact,
Encouraged her unto't, and led her on,
If she had been a villain to her death.
But he looking on her, and seeing in her eyes,
The image of fair virtue how it wept,
Gave back her vows, and freed her from his heart,
In that shape first she stood, but again placed her
As his most roy all mistress, and your wife.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Excellent voice go on, for I could stand
A tedious winter but to hear thee talk.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: So could not I without a rug gown.

sp.speaker: Doril.
sp.l: It hath been still a maxim, she's not chaste
That hath not been attempted, but she who hath stood
Temptation, and resisted. Gold is the purer
For being tried; and virtue put in act,
Appears more glorious, when it hath wrought itself
Out of those troubles which would stifle it.
Heaven was assaulted by the giants once,
Which showed Jove's power the greater: the pensive soul
Fighting with sin, the devil, and with death,
After the victory, triumphs and sings
Eternally amongst the blessed angels,
Crowned with perpetual peace and happiness:
But she for being virtuous must die,
For conquering her affections, for loving
Sincerely, and effectually, her lord;
For having not the cunning to dissemble,
But for being simple, chaste, and innocent,
Just, noble, beauteous, excellent in all,
Save what no common woman would have missed.
For this, and for this only she must die.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: No, she must live; and all the world must die,
To me, before a hair of her shall perish.
O I have wronged thy goodness, now I see't;
Who was before made blind with jealousy,
The heavens take thy part, and won't suffer
So much of worthiness to fall at once,
Lest nothing here but wickedness abound.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: Sir, will you hear me,

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Away, I will hear nothing but her angel's voice,
And that which spoke for her, which was no less,
It held such music in it, besides truth.
Wipe from thine eyes those tears; let messengers
Be sent to find the Earl my father forth,
And bring him back to the court, there to receive
Of us his dignities and favours trebled;
I am new framed again. Afflictions meet,
And mingling with our joys, make them more sweet.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: I do not like this.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.l: Nor I. (With you.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Fair one, pray stay, your brother would speak

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Sir, you may command me, and for his sake,
To th'utmost of my power, I am bound to you.
O my dear brother, how you joy my soul
To see you up again, in health, and lusty?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Place your thanks here kind sister, for to his skill.
Next under heaven, it must be attributed.

sp.speaker: Jul
sp.l: I do know it brother, and do thank him.
Heartily thank him, and the Duchess shall,
That owes him equally as much as we,
Thank him a better way.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: No lady, your thanks pays me really,
And I will never look for better pay,
Nor take, then comes from you; pray look upon me,
And see if you can fasten your affection
Upon a man so unworthy as my self.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Sir you are worthy of a better choice,
But let me for your own sake thus advise you,
If you have entertained any such thought,
(As I hope you are wiser) to part with it;
For trust me, this poor heart I carry here,
Is not mine own; I do but walk with it,
And keep it for another: pray no more sir,
Brother farewell, I shall be wanting to the Duchess.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Lost it, it cannot be.

sp.speaker: Doril.
sp.l: Now talking with you, plucking off this glove,
It fell out of my hand.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Seek good sir.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: And do we see the golden days again?
Does honour once more court us? then look up.
Look up my friends I say, and see your lord
Double and treble guilt; his happiness
Hatched, and inlaid, not to be worn out with time.
What do you look for?

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: A jewel we have lost.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: A jewel, let it be hanged, I'll give you every one
Jewels a piece, shall over value it,
There's not a friend I have, but shall have stones,
As fair and weighty as the Turk hath any,
And concubines like him, though not so many.
Ye shall good doctor, thou art so melancholy.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Come, let it alone.

sp.speaker: Doril.
sp.l: How? let it alone.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Yes, for lost it cannot be, if any find it,
When I am pleased to have it, I will send
A messenger shall fetch it with a vengeance.
Prithee forbear, and let us hear my lord.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: Gentlemen what will ye do? will ye come to court, and be graced by me, will you be knights or officers, gentlemen ushers, or of the bedchamber? speak what you'll be whilst I am i'the giving vain, and you are so.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: We'll wait on you tomorrow my good lord.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: You blue bottle basket hilt I talk not to you,
And th'other two are stupid, now I think on't:
Dorilus you were best leave the court; a man
Suspected once, is very seldom found
In his heart that suspects him to be sound:
There ye have a touch of my policy, farewell.

sp.speaker: Doril.
sp.l: Farewell my lord.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: Think on't.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: I'll warrant you.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: What's this? A ring: that is't and trust me,
A very pleasing one unto the eye,
Some lady lost it, for whose sake I'll wear it,
Until I find a challenger, it may he
'Twas lost a purpose and here dropped for me.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: Am I mad or drunk or the people, both: and blind too I think. For let me come up to them never so near, talk never so loud, gripe them never so hard, they see me not stare and gape, as if I were in the air, and ask, where are you. If we were out of favour, I should never wonder at it, but being restored, and in greater grace than ever, it somewhat troubles me: 'sfoot, and a lord cannot be acknowledged, what will be come of poor gentlemen: here come a couple, and sober as I take it, I'll try if they have not lost their eyesight.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: But that you justify it so vehemently,
I should not a believed it: lost again.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Again, and sent to prison, her father
Banished the court again, and all his honours,
Took again from him, and from's son,
And all's again as it was, and if not worse,

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: Nay then my admirations at an end. I remember nobody would know me last time. But these are a couple of honest fellows, and yet they serve a lord, if anybody have use of their eyes these will. By your leave gentlemen, did you see the young lord Frederick.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Where's he that asked that question?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: 'Sfoot I cannot see him, yet heard him plain,

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: The invisible voice is come again,

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: I believe so,

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: People are blind, that's certain — — look how they stare — I do not think there was ever any such thing in the world as an eye, a seeing eye. I know tailor's needles have eyes, and cheeses, but a discerning eye, that's the eye I would encounter with.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: It did me more good than my dinner, I protest, to see her transported to prison again.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: And so it did me I protest, for her brother's sake my lord Frederick Fadoudle.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: I wonder he is not taken yet, he'll fadoudle at the gallows, I believe whensoe'er he is, for I told the Duke what a saucy companion he was.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: I will requite your kindness instantly,

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: How now, what's that?

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: Will you too coxcombs never be uncoupled,

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.l: Who was that my lord?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Nay, I know not:

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: Who was that then?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Who was that said, who was that?

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: Marry it was I sir,

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: You, who are you?

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: One that'll bestow a ▪ little pains with you,

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Pray knock there no more my friend, that's the back gate, your best go about.

sp.speaker: Frede.
sp.p: I will do so, and wipe your noses for you.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: I'd rather you would let it alone, unless you had a finer handkerchief ▪

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: 'Tis the spirit of some porter, and wipes her with his frock.

sp.speaker: Ranoff.
sp.l: 'Zounds I'll not endure this: I'll draw first.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: And so will I.
Why do you not draw?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Hark, the voice asked why we do not draw.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Ay, I heard it, but I'll be hanged before I'll draw for that trick.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: And so will I to — see yonder's a company of gentlemen, let's fly to them for succour: are you walking.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Yes sir.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: We'd be glad of your company.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Here's an invisible voice follows us in the likeness of I know not what -

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: And plays upon us like a flute backward, and forward.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: We heard a voice indeed but felt no touch of any thing.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: No, it may be you are valiant and would strike again, but we are tender hearted, and ten to one, but it knows as much.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Why if you'll walk our way, we will guard you.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Yes sir, your way is ours now however .

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: Well I am lost I see, there's no hope that ever I shall be seen again of mortals; I walk i'the clouds; but that the other two before these, and before them others, could not perceive me, I should think I had with beating made the last pair cast a mist before their own eyes, Jubia and my lord of mischief with his two faces winter and summer.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: Sweet Julia kiss me.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: Ah you old whoremaster is the sign in Scorpio with you.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: Thou seest my power, how with a breath I turn.
And wind the Duke any way I please,
In spite of all those words wasted in air:
I plucked the Duchess from his arms again,
The only star of court, more than a Duchess,
Which is to be my mistress.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: Say you so, I'll master you anon.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: Prithee look up and smile upon me.

sp.speaker: Juli.
sp.l: Pray away.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: Come I have word sufficient nor will any longer be kept of thus weary of delay, I mean to work you.

sp.speaker: Jule
sp.l: Lay off your wicked hands.
Adders and scorpions shall as soon embrace me,
Shall my dear mistress that equally laments:
My adverse fate, which here's if not about it.
And in her tears lies bathed, breaking her sighs:
Into as many pieces, as if she strived
To number up her sins, which are no more,
Then will make truth appear that she must sin,
And shall I throw away all thought of her,
That altogether thinks of heaven and me,
Whom hourly she solicits and ascends,
And calls me along with her in her prayers,
Shall I forget this lady, and to lust
Prostrate myself to him that works her ruin.
First, may heaven point me out, his mark for vengeance.
And I unable to avoid the stroke.
Be rent and torn as thunder doth an oak,

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: Stay — you are too wilful.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Is that all?

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: Hear me — — I will speak what shall be liking to thee. Prithee come back; so well I do perceive thou lovest the Duchess, that her affliction's thine.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: They are.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: Canst thou cast off grief with her releasement?
If I shall bring her sound unto the Duke,
In every circumstance, and fix her sure:
Nay set her one stair higher than she was,
And make him honour what before he admired.
Wilt thou then make a passage for my love,
And open me away into thy heart?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I will.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: Will't thou give me a kiss upon the premises.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: I'll give you a kiss anon, in your good father the devil's name.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: I hold heaven in my arms, and all the joys:
Wilt thou be just to me?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: As you are unto me; for if you prove
The master of your word, I will be over mine the mistress,
And though it be a jewel I esteem,
I never saw how I could part with it better.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: Another kiss, and go and promise unto all thy friends, and to the Duchess self, her liberty.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: You are a villain.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: Ha.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: You are damned.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: What voice is that?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I heard none.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: I will cut your throat.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: Cut my throat.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: Ay, your weasand pipe, your gullet, this ungodly gullet.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: Swoons it pinched me by the throat.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: Your best cry out murder.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: This is another voice allied to that which pleaded for the Duchess, but not the same, and it is merely witchcraft. I fear thee not Devil, or devil's mate, friend or acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Who do you talk to?

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: A scurvy voice, I know not, nor do care for,
An yet it troubles me, I cannot see
The thing that sets it going. Be you
Careful and constant. In the afternoon
Come to my lodging, I will have the Duke there
And you shall be a witness of my wedding.
And of the subtle projects I have laid,
To execute your wishes, till then farewell.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Farewell.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: A pox upon thee whatsoe'er thou art.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: 'Twill come home.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: Show thyself and be the prince of devils,
I'll not fear thee.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: No, the great devil and you are all one, which shows I am no devil; for if I were, I durst not thus abuse

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: What art? (Thee.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: A pleasant fellow sir, and one of the noble science, for look you sir, there's a veny.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: O, swoons he has stabbed me.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: No sir no, I am a blunt fellow, and so my weapon; nay ▪ I wonot leave you thus.

sp.speaker: Doril.
sp.l: Here's my sister, but very sad methinks :
how now Julia, why so disconsolate.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: O brother we are undone: all's out of joint again
As much or rather more than ever.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: The duke's in old fit, and the poor Princess
Clapped up close prisoner, look to yourself
Or you are lost. (Me

sp.speaker: Dori.
sp.l: Be it so; for life is wearisome sister, do you love

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Why should you ask a question so frivolous.

sp.speaker: Dori.
sp.l: Do you?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: You know I do.

sp.speaker: Dori.
sp.p: Show it then; for till you satisfy me in my request, I shall make doubt of it.

sp.speaker: Jul
sp.l: Pray speak it.

sp.speaker: Dori.
sp.l: Here's a gentleman to whom I owe,
More than my parents gave me, more than
If fortune should look up and smile,
Prove a prodigal in favours to me;
And I should live to take 'em with this hand,
And with this, pay it as due tribute unto him ▪
See how he languishes, can take no rest,
No food, but thoughts which nourish him,
And sighs again for you, drinks his own tears,
And weeps them forth again, yet does not call you cruel,
Pray speak to him.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Why alas? brother I did tell this man
How hopeless I was, prayed him to desist,
And make some better choice.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: You did lady, but I must die first.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Why if you be so desperate a lover,
That you will die for me, think me the like,
That I can die as well for him I love.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: You were good company to go to heaven with.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Ay, but if either of you go that way, you take ▪
An ill course in your journey.

sp.speaker: Doril.
sp.l: Have you then placed your heart on any man ▪

sp.speaker: Iul
sp.l: Yes believe me, though I have made no noise
With sighs, able to blow up mountains.

sp.speaker: Doril.
sp.l: What is he?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: One that you praised yourself into my heart,
Although his youth and feature need no orator.

sp.speaker: Doril.
sp.l: I praised! Julia you wrong me.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: By Cupid's self I do not.

sp.speaker: Doril.
sp.l: Name him.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: 'Tis an unreasonable request in you,
But yet to show I am not ashamed of him,
It is young Bernard.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Who lady? pray speak that name again.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Young Bernard.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Bernard la Vere.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: The same.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: I thank you.

sp.speaker: Doril.
sp.l: Nay sister, once you are caught.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: But in no worse trap than her lover's arms

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Nor shall you ever be ashamed of him, nor yet
Repent you, for he will love as faithfully
As you, and live and die with you.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: There is no giving back, welcome my love,
And in a time that I did wish for thee;
Yet I shall startle you and try your temper:
For since I have found away how to infranchise
My poor afflicted mistress, I'll be pleasant.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: I never thought before, a man might be
In heaven and not know it, as to have a dwelling
In your heart and be ignorant of the bliss, is little less.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: O but my Bernard, we do never meet
With any happiness, but some kind of mischief
mingles still with it, yet 'tis more or less,
As you shall make of it, if you might take me now:
Why, I were worth your love, for I am yet;
(I did not lie much, if I said a virgin)
But without blushing I dare say a maid.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: It is not to be doubted.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: But it is to be lost.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: That is not to be doubted neither.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: But not on him, for so it is not lost,
To deal directly with you, I cannot bring,
That thing called maiden ▪ head, for it is promised.
And if you cannot love me without that,
Deal plainly then with me, as I with you,
And I will look out for another man:
Another handsome man a citizen.
That shall make much of me, and not a whit,
Love me the worse for want of such a trifle.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: I know sweet Julia you were ever merry,
And not beyond a maiden's modesty.
But this is very strange,

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: But not so strange as true, I am a witness of it,
She has given away her maiden head to the devil,
For an old whoremaster is little better.

sp.speaker: Dori.
sp.l: That is Fredericks voice.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: But as she said 'tis but a trifle: a cold commodity
A man may buy at some time of the year
Like cucumbers, at any time for a small ring,
A purse, or a pair of gloves, for so your country
Wenches part with them, your city for an apple.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: There's none if you see him.

sp.speaker: Dori.
sp.l: Not I.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: He has found the ring.

sp.speaker: Dori.
sp.l: Very likely.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: Nay most certain, and let him keep it, for being ignorant in the virtue of it, it may be some sport to us to hear him chase being lost to all mankind.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: Doctor thou droppest.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: The devil what art thou, I see thee not.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: No more, thou shalt him that does cuckold thee.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: That's true, whilst he enjoys the invisible ring.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: O you are a stout lover to be dejected thus, for such a vanity as a maidenhead is, you'd ill endure to have your wife run away with another man two or three year together, and afterwards brought home, and again accepted with suppers and with trumpets.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: A plaguey smart wench.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: But since it is so estimate a jewel,
Come my Barnard we'll not part with it,
But lay our heads together how to preserve it.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: Why but do you hear, shall I be lost thus
Will none of you acknowledge me, Julia,
Doctor Dorilus.

sp.speaker: Dori.
sp.l: Frederick by the voice.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: And Frederick by flesh and blood as good as any man or woman would desire, feel me else.

sp.speaker: Dori.
sp.l: I do feel a hand.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: And yet perceive nobody .

sp.speaker: Dori.
sp.l: Right.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: Right, but by your leave all is not right; either your eyes are drawn aside, or my body is taken asunder, and nothing left certain of me but a hand and a voice, mass here comes Smirke, I'll try the strength of his eyesight.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: I beseech you stay, here is a promise of some mirth.
sp.stage: Enter Smirke with sever all pots of colours.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: Smirke well met.

sp.speaker: Smi.
sp.l: Not so my friend, well overtaken you may say,
But I am in haste, therefore farewell.
sp.p: What are there rubs in the air, 'tis some little dandiprat, that I overrun, and ten to one he has broke his nose against my pipkin, where art thou?

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: Here.

sp.speaker: Smi.
sp.l: Here, where is that here.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: What has he got trow there painting: that it is, since you know me not, I'll bestow a little pains to picture you, that the best friend you have, shall hardly take acquaintance of you.

sp.speaker: Smi.
sp.p: A pox of these flies, they'll never leave ▪ sweet mutton, but my friend, my friend, he's gone poor fellow again.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: 'Tis strange you know not me.

sp.speaker: Smi.
sp.l: I should know that voice.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: You should do so, if you would call yourself to mind

sp.speaker: Smi.
sp.p: My young master Frederick and quondam lord where are you?

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: Here man here.

sp.speaker: Smi.
sp.p: Something plays with my nose I believe 'tis my whisking muschatus, now I am come i'the wind.

sp.speaker: Fre,
sp.l: What dost thou do with this painting smirk?

sp.speaker: Smi.
sp.p: Marry I mean to live by it and purpose to set up my old trade again. Fre. Thy old trade, what's that?

sp.speaker: Smi.
sp.p: Why a stainer, I have hired a shop not far from court. And I have painted the most horrible things that many men know not what to make of them, I drew Hercules a great while ago in the likeness of a man, and now every one says he looks like a lion. Then I drew Actaeon hunted with his own dogs, and they say 'tis like a citizen pursued with sergeants.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: Why, but canst thou draw any thing into proportion?

sp.speaker: Smi.
sp.p: Can I draw any thing into proportion; why, I will presently draw you backward or forward, a limb, 'twould do you good to behold it.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: And thou beest so good a workman, thou shalt draw my picture.

sp.speaker: Smi.
sp.p: I would be glad to see your face in, if it please you to come out of the cloud.

sp.speaker: Frede.
sp.p: Well Smirke, pray for me, I am a man, but in this world I have small store of money, and therefore cannot reward thee as I would, but hold thee, give me thy hand, I can see to take thee by it, there's a ring, 'twill yield thee somewhat.

sp.speaker: Smi.
sp.p: I thank you sir, it will serve to exchange for a coral for my son and heir when I have him.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Now step out altogether and salute him.

sp.speaker: All
sp.l: Good senior you are welcome to the light,

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: To the light: why, do you perceive me now?

sp.speaker: Dori.
sp.l: As plain as the earth we tread on.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: Where's Smirke?

sp.speaker: Smi.
sp.l: Here I am sir.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: Where, come near me, oh the ring, the ring,
Give me my ring again, I find the virtue,

sp.speaker: Smi
sp.l: Nay, soft, so play fools, nothing is surer than gift.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: Come near me that I may touch thee.

sp.speaker: Smi.
sp.p: I know what the proverb says, touch me and take me, and therefore I will keep aloft, 'sfoot he is strucken put blind, he gropes like a young novice, the contrary way. What are these blind too?

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: Good gentlemen help me to lay hold of him.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Lay hold of whom.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: Of Smirke.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.l: Smirke, why he is gone.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: No, he is here, I smell the oily rascal.

sp.speaker: Smi.
sp.p: They are all blind, or else I walk invisible, I'll try that presently.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: How now?

sp.speaker: Smi.
sp.p: Nothing but a flesh-fly forsooth lighted upon your lips, the place is full of hem — somebody has sprinkled invisible virgin's water upon me for I do go insensible. Here comes the two eggs, I shall go near to crack their crows, for the last abuse, but walking as I do, I will find out a better revenge.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: Sirrah I think it was much hereabout that we met with the taking voice that kicked us?

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.l: 'Twas indeed.

sp.speaker: Smi.
sp.p: I would kick you again, but that I have corns on my toes, I will only pencil you now. And because you have so much knavery and want colour for't I will begin with orange tawny.

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.l: What was that?

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.l: What,

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Someting crossed my nose.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.l: A door, a door, the fields are full of them.

sp.speaker: Smi.
sp.l: I'll give you the door too.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.l: There was another wiped me in the same place.

sp.speaker: Smi.
sp.l: 'Cause you are a knight, you shall bear a cross

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.l: How now?
'Sfoot I think some bird has wrayed in my eye.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: No 'tis nothing but the dew falls I think.
A pox on't, I am paid again.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.l: There are some gadflies sure abroad, let's make away.
Another wipe first.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.l: Why do you laugh my lord? ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Smi.
sp.l: Nay, I'll put in too, for my ha, ha, ha, ha.
This is a three man's laughter.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: But why do you laugh my lord? ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.l: Ha, ha, pray why do you laugh my lord?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: For nothing, for nothing, come prithee let's go.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.l: I pray let's go, ha ha,

sp.speaker: Smi.
sp.l: I am glad I have made you merry.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: Where art thou? So dear I love thee for this piece of knavery that I could kiss thee, prithee let me kiss thee

sp.speaker: Smi.
sp.l: No, no, kissing, I do bristle too much.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: I'll give thee another ring.

sp.speaker: Smi.
sp.p: No no, no more rings, I shall think myself an alderman, and grow proud then.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Come let him alone with it.

sp.speaker: Smi.
sp.p: If you know any lady that deals in complexion you may do me a kindness to acquaint her that Smirke the servingman is turned a painter.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: How now Carolus, how does my lord?

sp.speaker: Caro.
sp.l: Troth scurvily, as a lord may do in his case.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Why how is't man?

sp.speaker: Caro.
sp.p: Wicked, wicked, extreme wicked, he cannot say his prayers.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Why? is he speechless.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: What a pox is that to the purpose, has he made his will.

sp.speaker: Caro.
sp.p: Yes, and in his will he doth will and command that you two shall be whipped, and that he has bequeathed you for your legacy.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Let him bestow it upon his friends, we can live without it.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: But prithee sirrah, tell us the manner of his sickness which was wondrous strange and sudden.

sp.speaker: Caro.
sp.p: Why how should I know more than you, I am none of his physician.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: They say but be it spoken in private that a rat haunts him, is it so? thou canst tell.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: A rat, a pox of a rat, 'zblood I heard otherwise.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Well, let's hear what hast thou heard.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Marry sir that the Neopolitan canker has searched into his bones: and he lies buried in ulcers, stinks so that without perfumes, nobody is able to abide him. But mum mum, not a word of this I speak, it is amongst fellows and friends.

sp.speaker: Caro.
sp.p: 'Tis well you do so, for otherwise your legacies would be bestowed upon you, a yard or two of whipcord is no great cost, and the executors would go to the charge, 'zblood what rascals are you to utter this, you are the inventors of it.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Not I by this hand, I heard mine at my barbers,

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: And I heard mine at the apothecaries.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Why here's the misery of great men, they cannot scape the slanders of their slaves look you yonder goes one of the doctors, you were best (To be better satisfied) inquire of him.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Not I, I love not to be inquisitive.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: Where's any of my lords gentlemen there.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Here's a leash of us sir.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.p: One of you must instantly take horse, and ride to Doct or Lopez, and bring him hither with all speed that may be: his counsel is wanting, and it concerns your lords life, therefore make haste, and tell him so to: tell him the Duke will else be here before him; from whom, if so it happen, he will receive a check.

sp.speaker: Caro.
sp.l: We shall sir, we shall.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: The Duke, why is the Duke sent for?

sp.speaker: Caro
sp.l: Yes, and has sent word he will be here immediately.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: By'r lady sir, then 'tis to be thought the dangers more than every ague brings, and 'twill go hard with him.

sp.speaker: Caro.
sp.l: Why make not you more haste than to the doctors?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: I make more haste, why does not he or you?

sp.speaker: Caro.
sp.l: Ay, why I was not bidden.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Nor I.

sp.speaker: Caro.
sp.l: Why, nor I, more particular than you.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: But you must go that answered.

sp.speaker: Caro.
sp.l: Why you may go as well as I that answered.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: By this air not I.

sp.speaker: Caro.
sp.l: By this earth nor I.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: By this air, earth, fire and water too, not I: 'zblood I get no more than you, and why should I then?

sp.speaker: Caro.
sp.p: This is very well, suppose my lord for want of this same doctor now shall die.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Why, what can I help it. (You.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Why you may by fetching him.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: And so may

sp.speaker: Caro.
sp.l: And so may he.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: And so may you.

sp.speaker: Caro.
sp.l: I care not, nay do as you please.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Why, nor I neither.
sp.stage: A bed thrust out, enter lady the old lord, some other lady and aliens.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: 'Sfoot he shifts his room, I'll not be seen.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: By'r lady sir nor I.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: Who went for Lopez?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Ferdinand my lord.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: Is he not come yet?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: No my lord, nor gone yet I believe.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: O, my blood boils, as if the sun
Had darted all his beams into my entrails.
Short shot my soul, and like the shaft
Shot by great Hercules, fly till thou breakest,
Or else, strike through the body of the sun,
And fix thyself in heaven a brighter star.
What shall I do? Is there no power in physic?
Swoons are you dumb, doctors can you not talk,
Though you do nothing else?

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: Alas my lord; we know not what to say.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: Why then you might a said, that you can say,
That you know nothing, but your own
Privilege, to kill unpunished; yet are you apt
When nature works herself, to assume it yours.
O my torment, when wilt thou cease? get you gone,
Impostures as you are, and cousin people
That have faith in you; for I have found
No art, but voice among you.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: A way physicians, go; my lord thinks ye are fools,
And so do I: therefore begone, begone.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: Is not the Duke come yet?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: No my good lord; but here are the divines.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: They are very welcome.

sp.speaker: Bishops.
sp.l: How does your lordship?

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: Wondrous well satisfied in any point touching my salvation: only one burden on my conscience lies, for the Duke himself to take away.

sp.speaker: Caro.
sp.l: The Duke is come.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: Then all the rest I pray depart the room.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: How is it man?

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: Cheerful, wondrous cheerful, all this whole day I felt not such a minute.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: Be comforted good Raymond, methinks I see another age of life yet shine in thee, your eye is quick and sprightly, death doth not show himself in any part.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: Your grace is a good comforter, and your sight blows up this spark of life to such a light which is but as a twinkling before death.
sp.l: Therefore I do beseech your majesty,
As in this life and after death you'll stand,
In history to the last hour of time,
A just religious prince to which I know,
In your own inclination you aspire,
Even for the dukedom's peace, oh — your pardon:
My breath I find will fail me, — your pardon Duke.
And quickly speak it; or I shall not hear you.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: What, what shall I pardon? good Raymond speak, I gather by thy speech thou wouldst unfold, something of consequence; you must not part thus with me, therefore good Raymond speak, borrow a little time of death, and I will pay it back out of my life: dear Raymond do not leave me thus unsatisfied, for if you do, I'll follow you to learn it.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: O I have wronged you.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Never, never good Raymond.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: By that strong power which raises me I have,
And lends me breath to utter it; and this lady,
Where is she and the Princess all of ye,
For when you first began your jealousy,
Upon a small presumption, I as apt.
And sudden as yourself in fear to find,
The issue of a prince which heaven advert,
So basely bastardize, held up your thought,
Told you of former and familiar tricks,
In the like nature I had seen between them,
Which I protest was then out of my care,
That such a thing might be, rather than any crime,
That ever I knew she was guilty of,
Send for her therefore, and condemn your rash
False suppositions, and pardon mine,
That grew but out of yours, but once being grown,
It spread into more branches than your own,

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: What is thy purpose.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: Religious as the churches which is,
To clear all doubts and present truth,
In her own garments, to protect innocence,
And from her white hand lift her out of slanders,

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: By which you would infer my Duchess honest

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: By all the best hopes of a dying man,
This being a time not to jest breath away.
There does not live this day in christendom,
A Queen nor any woman through the world,
More truly virtuous, and as I speak truth,
So may I fail or find it.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Whether my joys are sensual or immortal,
I cannot say but surely I do feel,
And stand on such a change as if my soul,
Were melted into blood, or my blood turned.
To soul which lights, me up fresh tapers,
Whose instructive beams direct me to the heart
Of my dear Duchess, where chastity I find,
Hath built her temple — within there.

sp.speaker: Attend
sp.l: My lord.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Here, take my signet, deliver it to
Lord Lodwick, command him bring the Duchess,
And wait upon her hither, withal the speed
And diligence his duty can perform.

sp.speaker: Att.
sp.p: I shall my lord, and as I'm one of the honest men I am glad to hear it.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: O noble lady, how shall I look thy mistress i'the face, that blush at sight of thee? prithee stand by me, and embolden me, be my genius, prompt me what I shall say, or the scene's spoilt; I shall be out, my tongue doth falter for joy conceived of her great goodness, for grief of her much injury.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: As in the fiction, giants make war with heaven,
But are struck dead, so malice may strike at virtue;
But at last, I see the blow will light where it began.
Welcome my royal mistress, and I hope
Unto more comfort, than ever yet the Saxon
Court afforded, it bears the likeliest face
Upon us now.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Why do you kneel to me? the slanderer
Ought to ask pardon of the slandered,
My own law teaches it. Pray do you rise,
Or I will never think myself forgiven.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.p: Nay now my lord I fear you sent for me to mock me.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: God and all good men at my greatest need
Requite me with a mock, if I mean any.
O let me now expire, and be the happy messenger
To sing this news to heaven, such and so great.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: So happy reconcilements make the angels,
Tread the bright ring, and from the ordred spheres,
strikes heavenly music to all earthly ears:
Give me your royal pardon and remit me,
The hand of death lies cold and weighty on me,
And what is he but must sink under it,
Therefore go exercise your joys where grief,
May not be heard to express herself in tears,
For sorrow still sings loud unto our ears,

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: O my lord,

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: Dear princes speak no more, I know your heart,
But as you love my quiet, leave me to it,
For I do find an inclination to
Rest and sleep, and perhaps my last.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Come then let's leave him sickness is froward,
And one while company is pleasing to it,
Another while offensive, Raymond farewell,
Heaven to his mercy take or restore thee.

sp.speaker: Roy.
sp.l: Good Duke I thank thee, let me kiss thy hand,
And yours best Duchess, and lady yours, — so
Now if you will be gone, you may,
Sickness knows no manners.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: We'll trouble you no longer Raymond.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: Why I thank you, and all good lighten on you.
But not stay — Carolus.

sp.speaker: Caro.
sp.l: My lord.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: Are they all forth the room?

sp.speaker: Caro.
sp.l: Yes my lord.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: Active as fire I spring out of my grave then,
And will see some before me ere I die,
That are more fit for earth and heaven than I,
Fetch me some water, and a cup of wine,
I'll drink my own health and my lust shall pledge it,
Do I bear earth about me, sure I do not;
for in this ecstasy, I have no feeling,
No use of feet, but ride and rack i'th air,
Like a black cloud, holding in his hand lightning,
And in this a tempest, give me, and go
And understand the cause of Julia's stay,
It puts me into doubts and she should go
Away now with the Queen and cheat my hopes,
I have made a sick-man's plot of it,
But Julia is religious in her vows,
Knows what it is to swear, and what to break 'em.
How now villain, why returned without her?

sp.speaker: Caro.
sp.l: Why she is gone my lord.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: Be thoug thou gone too, and after her and fetch her,
And bring her to me, or lay down thy duty,
And let me never see it in a face,
Or an officious leg again presented,
Zounds are you scraping there when I forbid you.

sp.speaker: Caro.
sp.l: Alas my lord.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: My lord, my loggerhead, begone.

sp.speaker: Caro.
sp.p: O madam, you come like to the Halcyon, and bring fair weather with you.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: Thou art my truth, and I will study thee,
No more shall misbelief enter my thoughts:
For thy idea standing in my heart,
As in a temple shall fright all false suggestions,
To the Tartars. Give me instead of laurel,
For my deed, a sugared kiss, and crown my joys.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Away you are a villain, I came back to tell you so: and long life which is a blessing to others, unto thee's a curse: thou shame of such a reverence dost not see, to what a monster lust in thee is grown: at lest in men's imaginations.
sp.l: A man as old in show as time himself,
Made up for counsel like another Nestor:
At least in men's imaginations,
To be so monstrous goatishly inclined.
O fie my lord! think with yourself this ill,
Provokes not in the flesh, but in your will:
Your blood moves slow and cold and all the fire,
That strikes up any heat, is in desire:
I blush for you, think of it.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: Yes I'll think of it, but you shall give me time,
And you and I will now go and consult of it.

sp.speaker: Iul,
sp.l: Keep of.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: Why you wonot stab.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Yes to the heart believe it.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: Why then a combat; look you, I am provided too
Will you yield now?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: This would show handsome on a stage,
An old man and a woman at the point:
Believe it I'll stab too.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Thy worst: for I will mine,

sp.speaker: Ray,
sp.l: This is scurvy wooing, Julia no more.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Farewell then, and repent,

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: Nay then you stir me, yield, or I will force thee.
And after pay, thy perjury with death,
Are you so mannish.
sp.stage: Enter Duke, Duchess and all the rest spectators.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Desist vild ravisher.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: Ha, the Duke, than rage rise high in me,
And add unto this wickedness a worse.
sp.stage: Enter Bernard with his rapier drawn.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Villain, what wilt thou do, keep of.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: O I am lost.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: A guard.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Cease on the traitor, — oh that those hairs,
Which are the badge of truth and as I thought,
The care of her should shrouded such villainies,
So monstrously betraying and abusing:
Away with him to death.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: To death.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Yes a cruel and a lasting.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: I beseech your grace.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Wilt thou beg for him whom he so hath wronged
And which is more, made me the instrument?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Yes, good my lord his pardon?

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Prithee sweet no more, ask any thing but that,
Let law be of no force then in my land,
If I forgive such traitors.
O where is Dorilus?
That innocent and excellent good man:
If he be living, let him be brought to me
That I may honour him, if dead lament,
And wash him with my tears, sit on his Hearst
And ask forgive of his gentle spirit,
Lest it do haunt me being his murderer.

sp.speaker: Guido
sp.l: Justice, justice, my sovereign.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: What art thou comest for justice?

sp.speaker: Guido
sp.p: One that under your authority performs it upon others.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Perform it upon me for I am a murderer.

sp.speaker: Guido
sp.l: My lord.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: A murderer of my friends, of virtuous men,
Virtue herself did very hardly scape me.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Good my lord.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: I must see Dorilus alive or dead,
To view how big the wound was that I gave him,
For I will have grief dig one in my breast,
As deep as it is, and as mortal too.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Why here is Dorilus.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Prayers of princes fall on thee, dost thou live
To tell me that my sword doth want an edge,
But when it strikes offenders, rise Dorilus:
And thus unto thy mistress I present thee,
As the best jewel that I have to give her,
For a true servant is of that esteem.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Sir, I thank you, but I return him back,
As fittest for your service.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: Here's giving and taking as if they'd both be rid of him.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Why I thank thee, and I receive him gladly.
Now where's he that would have justice?

sp.speaker: Guido
sp.l: Here my liege.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Against whom wouldst thou have justice?

sp.speaker: Guido
sp.l: Against the president of Wittenberg.
Who falling foul with the learned Landoff
Tutor unto my son, is thought by most
And of the wisest of the university,
To have by some treacherous plot made them away,
He nor my son having been seen ere since.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: Why here is Landoff sir, your poor friend in safety.

sp.speaker: Guido
sp.l: Landoff, where is my son?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Here sir, with a daughter to boot.

sp.speaker: Guido
sp.p: Now God's blessing a'thy heart, if thou hast conferred me thus.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: E'en thus sir.
Rise with my blessing on you both.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: So they are owned, nobody calls upon me, nor regards me, nor to say the truth, I regard nobody: the loss of my invisible ring has broke my heart, now when I knew the virtue of it, to lose it, and to an idiot, an innocent, that deserves not to understand the virtue of it, what dainty devices might I have had in every chamber of the court, seen such a lord kiss such a lady the wrong way, such a knight, lie with his chambermaid, and his lady with her groom, the usher with the waiting-gentlewoman, and the page with all. Phoebus himself must a come short of those things, I should ha' seen, for one invisible ring would discover another.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: How now, what's the cause of this? why kneel you all?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: For that which I join with them too.
Lord Raymond's life, banish him the court,
And let him be confined to his house i'th country.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Thou must not ask twice what I shall deny,
Rise, 'tis granted you; see you have good friends,
And a gracious mistress.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: I see't, and shame to see myself,
How had the devil blinded me, I could not
See your rare virtues? O let my penitence,
Which if it be not zealous, just heavens strike,
That breath into my throat, again which forms,
The words I utter, and let 'em strangle me:
Let my true penitence I say beget,
Another virtue in you, besides mercy,
Credulity that I am truly sorry,
For the bold mischiefs 'gainst you and my prince:
A guilty conscience followed by despair,
Light on all traitors to their sovereign,
wants to the extrem'st sickness without succour,
Without all good man's pity and their prayers,
Fall on the slanderers of all your sex:
Diseases rot him living; dead no grave,
But ravenous fowls, become his sepulchre,
His bones kicked up and down by his enemies,
And charitable men allow of it,
Hell and the devils, plying him with torments:
Bast his black soul, that he may roar so loud:
As to the earth crying he heard may be,
Who slanders women, may be damned like men.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Will there be such revels say you.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Yes, but no words, for it must be kept private.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Private, why there are gone out proclamations, that whosoever can by device, or any quick conceits delight the Duchess, he shall have correspondent to his quality an annual stipend besides the favour of the Duke for ever.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Such a thing was talked of, for the Duke now dotes far more on the Duchess then at first; and whatsoever is done, is to delight her.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: 'Tis a better hearing than the old jealousies.
What's your lord confined to his house i'the country.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: And how find you your new lord.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p:
Very noble, and so doth bear himself to every
man, hark, yonder's such a coll with the musicians, the masquers, and the dancers, who now are practising.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Is not the poet amongst them.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Yes, and which is a miracle a masquer,
The learned, Landoff, who now although he be
A professed academian,
Has laid aside his graver weightier studies,
To exercise his skill not yet forgotten,
Being brought up a page at court, and practised
Much in that quality — hark I must leave you,
I have a charge committed to me.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: May I not under your protection,
Behold the sports.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: I cannot tell, I will not promise you,
For my lord's very strict, I'll do my best.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Why I thank you.

sp.speaker: Smirke
sp.p:
I do not know how it comes about that I should be lost thus; villainous witchcraft will never be left, I am fain to give over my shop, but I had broke; howsoever my painting cloth was so rotten, it could not hold together, but the best is, I shall live like a gentleman, because I walk invisible, nay I am not only invisible to other men, but to myself: I went this morning to a lookingglass, to be acquainted with this comely countenance, the devil of countenance there was to be acquainted with; the glass seemed to me like a deep water, that I began to feel with my hands for fear I might a been drowned: but finding myself above ground, and hunger tumbling like a Porcupine in my maw, and doing the Somerset in my guts, I smelled a sirloin of beef hot from the spit followed the train close, set in my foot,
drew my knife, sliced me off a collop, clapped it upon a penny loaf, went me to a side table, consumed it without anybody saying much good do you, or the devil choke you. Set my lips to a flagon of beer, drunk twice with a breath, set it down again, took it up again, and drunk it as dry as a biscuit: so that I perceive I cannot starve. And for clothes, 'tis no matter how I go, nobody sees me.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Pray give 'em great charge at the outward doors
They admit none but such as are courtiers,
The hall must not be pestered. Where's Ferdinand?

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Here my lord.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Pray have a care those lights be not offensive unto the ladies, they hang suspiciously, and let the hangings be removed.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: They shall my lord, where's Pedro?

sp.speaker: Pedro.
sp.l: Here sir.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Look to those lights I pray, my lord is very angry, fearing they might do trespass, and those hangings must be removed.

sp.speaker: Pedro.
sp.l: They shall sir, — where's any of the grooms?

sp.speaker: Groom.
sp.l: Here sir.

sp.speaker: Pedro.
sp.p: Pray look to these lights, and let the hangings be removed, the gentleman usher has commanded it.

sp.speaker: Groom
sp.p: They shall sir, where's the fellow here should look unto these lights, things are done so untowardly.

sp.speaker: Smirke
sp.p: nobody sees me, I come in like the air, when lords and ladies stand waiting for this officer and tother officer, country gentlemen their pates broke, and citizens wives thrust up and down in every corner, their husbands kept out with flame and torch, glad to fetch a nap i'th cloisters.

sp.speaker: Groom.
sp.p: Bear back there, bear back, room for my lord Lodwick.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Here madam you shall face the Duke and Duchess, 'tis the best place to see in all the hall.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: I thank your honour.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Have a little patience, the revels will begin immediately.

sp.speaker: Grooms.
sp.p: Room for my lord, bear back, swoons whither would you?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Well said, thou dost more good with thy oaths then all they with their truncheons.

sp.speaker: Groom
sp.l: The Duke is coming.
sp.stage: Music. Envy and pleasure pass o'er the stage.

sp.speaker: Envy.
sp.l: Sports are intending which I will have crossed.
Add clouds tonight , that pleasure may be lost.

sp.speaker: Pleasure
sp.l: Envy thou wound'st thyself in spite of thee,
This I break forth, out of obscurity.

sp.speaker: Smir.
sp.l: This is the four winds driving of five
Devils — this same ring would fain give
Me the slip, I must e'en pocket him, for
Fear of the worst.

sp.speaker: Groom.
sp.l: How now sirrah, what make you here?

sp.speaker: Smir.
sp.l: Why, do you see me?

sp.speaker: Groom.
sp.p: See you, yes marry do I: and get you gone quickly, or you shall feel — I see you, go, begone this is no place for such as you.

sp.speaker: Smirk.
sp.p: Humh: am I become a wretch again, and mortal?

sp.speaker: Smirk.
sp.p: I am got in again, and have found the trick of it, thanks my dear gem; a man may have an invisible ring I see, and not know of it; I wondered that I grew palpable, now I perceive how the matter went: thanks my dear gem, I say still, I will not lose this finger that I have my invisible ring upon, for the best joint at the bars.

Is this all the devices, sports, and delights, the Duke shall have for his money: the proclamation promised reward for him that could show any varieties, and is't all come to a dull masque? I'll show his grace some sport myself, with help of my invisible ring, which now must off again. By your majesty's leave, and the rest of the honourable —

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: How now, what's he?

sp.speaker: Smirk.
sp.p: What's he? Why he is the miracle of your kingdom.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: How the miracle!

sp.speaker: Smirk.
sp.p: Ay, and can do wonders — now you see me you know me.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Yes sir, I do know you.

sp.speaker: Smir.
sp.l: And you know not me, you know nobody .
But keep off my lord.

sp.speaker: Doril.
sp.l: Prithee keep off.

sp.speaker: Smir.
sp.l: You see me you say, Duke I speak to thee.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Yes sir, I see you.

sp.speaker: Smir.
sp.l: And you all see me.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.l: We do all see you.

sp.speaker: Smirk.
sp.p: Very good, and I do see all you: but what's that to the purpose?

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.l: Very little to purpose indeed,

sp.speaker: Smir.
sp.l: Shall I demonstrate matter of art.
And have nothing for my pains?

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: Yes marry shall you, does not the proclamation tell you shall.

sp.speaker: Smir.
sp.l: Proclamations may say what they list,
Something in hand doth well.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Somebody give him something.

sp.speaker: Smir.
sp.p: Ay, but nobody hears not on that ear, yet because I — wonot do royalty wrong, in suspecting your bounty — you see me you say.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Yes we do see you.

sp.speaker: Smir.
sp.l: You do. Who sees me now?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Trust me not I, he is invisible to me.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: And me.

sp.speaker: Dori.
sp.l: To all.

sp.speaker: Smir,
sp.p: I should be sorry else; for, and my invisible ring should not keep his old virtue, I would hang myself directly.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: Prithee appear again.

sp.speaker: Smir.
sp.l: I will have majesty call me first.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Why the Duke does call you.

sp.speaker: Smir.
sp.l: Let me hear him vuia voce, Smirke is my name
A well beloved subject, once a painter,
But now esquire of the invisible ring.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: Smirke, and our well-beloved subject, once a painter, but now esquire of the invisible ring.
sp.l: I conjure thee to appear again.

sp.speaker: Smir.
sp.l: See here I am, what wouldst thou mighty monarch

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: I do command thee let me see the ring.
By which thou walkst invisible.

sp.speaker: Smir.
sp.l: I do command thee not to command me that,
For from my invisible ring I will not part.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Lay hands upon him for a sorcerer.

sp.speaker: Smir.
sp.l: Assist me my dear ring, no hands upon me,
For being invisible, I am a prince,
And being a prince no hands is to be laid on me;
Treason doth never prosper.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: He is gone again.

sp.speaker: Smi.
sp.l: You follow me by scent, but never find me by sight.
I'll warrant you.
sp.stage: Enter spirit, Landoff, whispering with him.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Seize it and fly.

sp.speaker: Spirit
sp.l: I am gone.

sp.speaker: Smir.
sp.l: O, o, o.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: How, who is that exclaims.

sp.speaker: Smir.
sp.l: The cramps in my finger.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: The cramp.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: O sir, now you are visible again.

sp.speaker: Smir.
sp.p: My ring is gone now, the devil go with it, for a my conscience he fetched it.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: What have you lost your ring.

sp.speaker: Smir.
sp.p: Ay, ay, and my middle finger, which served me for more use than all the rest.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: That's strange.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: But what is become of the ring.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.l: Pardon me liege, that virtue that it held,
Came from my art, and at some fitter time,
I will acquaint you with the passages,
How, and the cause for what it was intended:
Your gracious Duchess knows and felt the worth,

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Thy knowledge in good arts is found Landoff,
Nor will we be inquisitive of more.
Then thou shalt think it fit to be revealed:
for all thy actions have been just and loyal,

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: What means this trumpet,

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Perhaps some new delights and rarer.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.l: Thus was I bidden to my sovereign,
Fall on my face, now rise I up again
To render to the lady's fair salutes,
And give them all their worthy attributes,
Wonder not that I resolutely come,
Boldly thus daring press into this room,
For from a lord and knight of eminent note,
I bring this challenge; such as can read may know't.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: Very succinct and peremptory.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: For this day I am master of the revels.
sp.p:
Be it known unto all men that I, — of the court, of Saxony, traveller, by degree a lord, and a professed champion for all ladies in the lists of peace, do challenge all courtiers whatsoever, without exceptions, native or strangers, to confer, court, or compliment, in silence with discursive motion and true action of the face, hand, body, and leg, and afterwards with the volubility of the tongue, to talk longest, fastest and loudest, for sense I stand not upon it, being seldom regarded by the party courted, therefore indeed belongs not to the courtier: also be it farther known that my assistants, agents, or seconds, doth challenge likewise all courtiers whatsoever, at the true compendious form of compiling epistles, alias love-letters, to ladies or mistresses, either in prose or verse, with proverbs, or without proverbs, with sentences, or without sentences, figures, or any other matter, to be performed extempore, or not extempore, according as it shall please the challenged, which is to say,
the defendant to determine: all which, that aforesaid, as well as this now spoken of, shall be performed by the said challengers instantly; who only staying to hear of any opponents, are both ready to enter.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Here is unexpected sport.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Let 'em enter, they shall be answered; Smirke, thou shalt be my second.

sp.speaker: Smi.
sp.p: Shall I, that's some comfort yet, to put the loss of the ring out of my thought.
sp.l: Shall I answer the epistoler?

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: Ay, marry shalt thou.
