sp.speaker: Smi.
sp.p: I'll pistol and pestle him, I'll warrant him, he was ne'er so pounded in his life, I'll scorn to begin after my hearty commendations with him.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.l: Hark, they approach.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Which is my antagonist?

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: I am he.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.l: And who is mine?

sp.speaker: Smi.
sp.l: Behold the man, with pen and ink provided.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.l: Poor fool, thou wilt but make thyself derided

sp.speaker: Smi.
sp.p: So nimble in rhyme, I'll first break your head in prose, and afterwards whip you in verse, I'll lambast you in completes.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Nay I will not lose the honour of being the courted lady.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: When my talking time comes I will thank you lady in language.

Mark how my challenge goes, 'twas not to talk sense only, but longest, fastest, loudest, and you our talk me that way, I'll give you my tongue and every tooth I have to make trotters on, for I was born and
bred and nursed a talker, and of my quality, this lady has had some small experience, for I did promise her to prove a talker, and for her sake do now profess, and practis't and 'tis in vain for any creature to contend with me, — I have put down the lawyers of all nations, and all women, gossips at christenings, after they have drunk wine the midwife being there, words flow out of my mouth like water from the clouds, to make a deluge, to drown all voices but my own, which drums nor trumpets, nor a sea flight can do.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: But a thump of the guts will.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: O.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: 'Tis excellent; sweet lady to hear words,
Though they want matter, for silence does betray,
A bashfulness in man, unmeet for courtiers,
For he that has a bold tongue and a free,
Can never want th'affection of ladies,
Nor is it fit he should, for he can keep 'Them,
Walking at midnight with a tedious tale,
And longer 'tis the better, because sleep
Being accounted as some use to call it,
Death's image, other some his elder brother,
By how much we do use it, by so much less,
We live in this world and lose time and pleasure,
Which both to rich and poor is the chief treasure,
Why do not you talk now.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Talk? If I have breath, enough to live, I care not.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Nay, and you give out, you have lost the day.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: I had not fair play shown me,

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: Stratagems are to be allowed, against all adversaries.
I'll have judgement on't.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Ay, ay, lawful. lawful.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: Lawful let it be then, but if ever I challenge a man of his hands, to a trial of skill with the tongue again, I'll forswear talking all days of my life, and that I would be loath to do — if I do not feel the very breath that should have been spent in words onwards, to twattle downward, I am a villain.

sp.speaker: Smirke
sp.p: I believe I smell the meaning, stand farther off, and give room to me and the epistoler, you challenge all men to compose?

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.l: I do.

sp.speaker: Smi,
sp.p: With figures or without figures, with sentences or without sentences.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.l: 'Tis right,

sp.speaker: Smi.
sp.l: Draw out your pen and inkhorn, I am for you.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Give 'em room, and set a table forth.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.l: With expedition too, I put in that.

sp.speaker: Smi.
sp.p: No, expedition belongs to clerks, and not to secretaries, celerity if you will.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.l: Ay sir, celerity, I mean so.

sp.speaker: Smi.
sp.l: No more but so, a word's enough.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: But what's the subject?

sp.speaker: Smi.
sp.p: Why each of us is to indite an epistle to our mistress, is it not so?

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.l: Right.

sp.speaker: Smi.
sp.l: Then write.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: This will be good mirth I hope.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Ridiculous enough.

sp.speaker: Fre,
sp.p: So it should be, and yet my little smirk here has conceit, he'll have some flashes.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: A couple of pretty scribes.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: The challenger has the advantage, he might premeditate.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p:
No matter, smirks best at a start, his wit is like
your hackney, all a gallop, to which he says, utere diligentia, nec sis tantus cessator et calcoribus indigeas, which is clawing the pole, as for example in your challenger.

sp.speaker: Dori.
sp.l: He has rubbed it out it seems.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: Smirke goes on smoothly, without any rub,

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Yet there he had one.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Hold bias, and a sentence then.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.l: Scripsi.

sp.speaker: Smi.
sp.l: Et scripsi.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Very good, now lordings lend your cares.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.l: I will read it first myself.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: And good reason.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.l: Fairest in the world, and sweetest upon earth.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: So.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.l: I remember my duty to you in black and white.

sp.speaker: Smi.
sp.l: I would it had been black and blue.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Peace.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: For all colours else wave under the standard of your beauty.

sp.speaker: Smi.
sp.p: I wonder what part of her, is goose-turd green: that's a colour.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.l: You are the mistress of beauty.

sp.speaker: Smi.
sp.l: I would a said the Queen or empress.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.l: And all other women are but your handmaids.

sp.speaker: Smi.
sp.l: O abominable barren.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: Nay smirk silence, you must not interrupt your adversary.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: I can say nothing without saying too much, nor say too much without saying nothing.

sp.speaker: Smi.
sp.p: I must say nothing, or else I would say something, but here it is shall shame thee.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: methinks when thou stood in the sun with thy feather on thy head, and thy fan in thy hand, thou lookest like the phoenix of the East Indies, burning in spices, for cloves, mace, and nutmegs are in thy breath.

sp.speaker: Smi.
sp.l: She would make an excellent wassail-bowl.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Again.

sp.speaker: Smi.
sp.l: I have done.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: The apples of thy breast are like the lemons of Arabia, which makes the vessel so sweet it can never smell of the cask.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: If she should that might prove the brewer's fault.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Being come to your middle I must draw to an end, for my end is at the middle because of the proverb. In medio consistet virtus, and so I conclude: yours while mine own, and afterwards if it were possible Marmaduke Ranoff.

sp.speaker: Smi.
sp.l: Well now let me run on, judgement I crave.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: Which thou shalt have.

sp.speaker: Smir.
sp.p: Illustrious, bright shining, well spoken, and blood stirring lady.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Ay, marry sir.

sp.speaker: Smir.
sp.p: If the rope of my capacity, could reach to the belfry of your beauty, these words of mine like silver bells, might be worthy to hang in the ears of your favour but the ladder of my invention is too low to climb up to the steeple of your understanding.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Excellent Smirke.

sp.speaker: Smir.
sp.p: If it were not, I should ring out my mind to you in a sweet peal of most savoury conceits. For your face it is like the sun, no man is able to endure it.

sp.speaker: All
sp.l: That's very good.

sp.speaker: Smi.
sp.p:
Your forehead which I will neither compare unto alabaster, nor to the lily, but it is as it is, and
so are both your eyes, for your nose, it is a well arched bridge, which for brevity's sake I pass over: your cheeks are like a good comedy, worthy to be clapped: your lips, and your teeth are incomparable; your tongue like the instrument of Orpheus, able to tame the furies: to handle every part of you were too much, but some particular part, no man can sufficient.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: Prithee let me give thee a box on the care, for that conceit.

sp.speaker: Smi.
sp.l: No my good lord, pray keep your bounties.
sp.p: From top to toe you are a sweet vessel of delight, I dare not say a barrel, for oftentimes with much jolting, the brewer beats out the bunghole, and so the good liquor runs out, but you contain yours although not hooped about with the old fashioned farthingale, but after the new fashion tied up with points, to untruss at your pleasure, in which pleasure I leave you, fairest of a hundred, and wittiest of a thousand: resting in little rest, till I rest wholly yours, in the downe-bed of affection, wherever standing to my utmost, I rest all in all yours.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: Could any man say more.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Your censures hereafter gentlemen; now sir I challenge you in verse, in praise of tall women, and little women, and choose your subject, which you refuse I'll take.

sp.speaker: Smir.
sp.l: Why then I'll take your little women.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.l: And I your lusty — proceed.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Ay, here will be some sport now.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: The Duke calls to see the epistles.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: And they are worth his perusal.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p:
We must have patience, for this verse wonot
come of so roundly as your prose.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Best have a song to entertain the time.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.l: 'Twere not a miss.
Music —

sp.speaker: Ranof.
sp.l: Scripsi.

sp.speaker: Smir.
sp.p: Said non feci, stay a little, here's a couple of lines, a halter on 'em, they wonot twist handsomely, go forward I have ended.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Attention.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.l: Listen you tall and likewise you low man,
I sing the praises of a bouncing woman.
A full well set big-boned and fairly jointed,
Fit to bid welcome men that are best appointed.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.l: Excellent.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.l: To your tall woman your little one is nothing,
No more than is a high thing to a low thing.

sp.speaker: All
sp.l: That's true.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.l: For your small dandiprat, I hope there's no man
That thinks her but a hobby horse to woman.
A thing to be forgotten and never known,
But on a holiday to the rout shown.
In wars the basilisk is preferred
Before the musket, and is louder heard.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: There's an error little and loud my friend, but pass it.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.l: In every triumph where there is excess,
The greater always putteth down the less.
The lioness is more admired at,
Than her epitome, which is a cat.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: The fool grows serious.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: He has stolen it certainly.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: No faith, it may be his own, for I think his brain
A little crazed, and mad men shoot forth strange things.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.l: But to weak understandings now I come,
Is your small taber music to your drum.

sp.speaker: Smir.
sp.p: Hum drum, he has lightened within an inch of a conceit of mine.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.l: Or in instrument of peace, can there that trial
Be made upon a kit as a base viol.
Judge you my masters, that on both have played,
It is but my opinion, and I have said.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: Believe it he has said well, Smirke look to yourself.

sp.speaker: Smir.
sp.l: I warrant you. Give me audience.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Silence.

sp.speaker: Smir.
sp.l: In praise of little women I begin.
And will maintain what I have entered in.
Is not your parochit or marmoset
In more request than your baboon or parrot.
Give but your little wench freely her liquour,
And to bed send her you will find her quicker;
Perter, nimbler, both to kiss and cog,
Than your great wench that'll lie like a log.
And he that all day at the drum doth labour,
Would at night gladly play upon a taber.
I hope there's no man, but of this belief,
That veal's more sweet and nourishing then beef:
Small meats is still preferred; for ask your glutton,
He'll always say, lamb's sweeter than your mutton.
Your smelled than Whiting firmer is and sounder,
Nor must your place compare with your neat flounder.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Well said, now thou art in good victuals thou'lt never out.

sp.speaker: Smir.
sp.l: In fish or flesh I'll prove it to each wight,
A larks leg, than the body of a kite
Is better far: our bakers always make
The finest flower in the lesser cake.
And I'll be judge by those that roots do eat,
That your small turnip's better than your great.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.l: I am of thy mind too.

sp.speaker: Smir.
sp.l: Who list to be resolved, let 'em both try;
In that belief I live, in that I'll die.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Incomparable Smirke, thou hast my voice: judgement.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: A smirk, a smirk.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Loath to grow tedious, yet once more we would try
To give content out of variety.
With once dance more this night sports we'll end,
Your pardon if with too much zeal we offend.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Landoff we thank thee, and wish if any be,
All that are here, be pleased as well as we.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
